lines.value: his performance in the 400 metres in paris stood as a european record for 12 years until beaten by another british athlete godfrey brown at the berlin olympics in 1936
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the olympics and graduation from the university of edinburgh liddell continued to compete
lines.name: English

lines.value: his refusal to compete on sunday meant he had also missed the olympic 4 x 400 relay in which britain finished third
lines.name: English

lines.value: shortly after the games his final leg in the 4 x 400 metres race in a british empire vs usa contest helped secure the victory over the gold medal winning americans
lines.name: English

lines.value: a year later in 1925 at the scottish amateur athletics association saaa meeting in hampden park in glasgow he equalled his scottish championship record of 10.0 seconds in the 100 won the 220 yard contest in 22.2 seconds won the 440 yard contest in 47.7 and participated in a winning relay team
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was only the fourth athlete to have won all three sprints at the saaa achieving this feat in 1924 and 1925
lines.name: English

lines.value: these were his final races on british soil
lines.name: English

lines.value: because of his birth and death in china some of that country's olympic literature lists liddell as china's first olympic champion
lines.name: English

lines.value: liddell returned to northern china to serve as a missionary like his parents from 1925 to 1943 - first in tianjin and later in the town of xiaozhang simplified chinese 肖张镇 zaoqiang county hengshui hebei province an extremely poor area that had suffered during the country's civil wars and had become a particularly treacherous battleground with the invading japanese
lines.name: English

lines.value: during his time in china as a missionary liddell continued to compete sporadically including wins over members of the 1928 french and japanese olympic teams in the 200 and 400 metres at the south manchurian railway celebrations in china in 1928 and a victory at the 1930 north china championship
lines.name: English

lines.value: he returned to scotland only twice in 1932 and again in 1939
lines.name: English

lines.value: on one occasion he was asked if he ever regretted his decision to leave behind the fame and glory of athletics
lines.name: English

lines.value: liddell responded it's natural for a chap to think over all that sometimes but i'm glad i'm at the work i'm engaged in now
lines.name: English

lines.value: a fellow's life counts for far more at this than the other liddell's first job as a missionary was as a teacher at an anglo chinese college grades 1 12 for wealthy chinese students
lines.name: English

lines.value: while he is best known for athletics his true passion was found in his missionary work
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was believed that by teaching the children of the wealthy they would become influential figures in china and promote christian values
lines.name: English

lines.value: liddell used his athletic experience to train boys in a number of different sports
lines.name: English

lines.value: one of his many responsibilities was that of superintendent of the sunday school at union church where his father was pastor
lines.name: English

lines.value: liddell lived at 38 chongqing dao formerly known as cambridge road in tianjin where a plaque commemorates his residence
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also helped build the minyuan stadium in tianjin
lines.name: English

lines.value: he suggested that it be copied exactly from chelsea's football ground where he had competed and was said to be his favourite running venue
lines.name: English

lines.value: during his first furlough from missionary work in 1932 he was ordained a minister of religion
lines.name: English

lines.value: on his return to china he married florence mackenzie of canadian missionary parentage in tianjin in 1934
lines.name: English

lines.value: liddell courted his future wife by taking her for lunch to the famous kiesling restaurant which is still open in tianjin
lines.name: English

lines.value: the couple had three daughters patricia heather and maureen the last of whom he would not live to see
lines.name: English

lines.value: the school where liddell taught is still in use today
lines.name: English

lines.value: one of his daughters visited tianjin in 1991 and presented the headmaster of the school with one of the medals that liddell had won for athletics
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1941 life in china had become so dangerous because of japanese aggression that the british government advised british nationals to leave
lines.name: English

lines.value: florence who was pregnant with maureen and the children left for canada to stay with her family when liddell accepted a position at a rural mission station in xiaozhang which served the poor
lines.name: English

lines.value: he joined his brother rob who was a doctor there
lines.name: English

lines.value: the station was severely short of help and the missionaries there were exhausted
lines.name: English

lines.value: a constant stream of locals came at all hours for medical treatment
lines.name: English

lines.value: liddell arrived at the station in time to relieve his brother who was ill and needing to go on furlough
lines.name: English

lines.value: liddell suffered many hardships himself at the mission
lines.name: English

lines.value: as fighting between the chinese eighth route army and invading japanese reached xiaozhang the japanese took over the mission station and liddell returned to tianjin
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1943 he was interned at the weihsien internment camp in the modern city of weifang with the members of the china inland mission chefoo school in the city now known as yantai and many others
lines.name: English

lines.value: liddell became a leader and organiser at the camp but food medicine and other supplies were scarce
lines.name: English

lines.value: there were many cliques in the camp and when some rich businessmen managed to smuggle in some eggs liddell shamed them into sharing them
lines.name: English

lines.value: while fellow missionaries formed cliques moralised and acted selfishly liddell busied himself by helping the elderly teaching at the camp school bible classes arranging games and by teaching science to the children who referred to him as uncle eric
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was also claimed that one sunday liddell refereed a hockey match to stop fighting amongst the players as he was trusted not to take sides
lines.name: English

lines.value: one of his fellow internees norman cliff later wrote a book about his experiences in the camp called the courtyard of the happy way chinese 樂道院 also translated as the campus of loving truth which detailed the remarkable characters in the camp
lines.name: English

lines.value: cliff described liddell as the finest christian gentleman it has been my pleasure to meet
lines.name: English

lines.value: in all the time in the camp i never heard him say a bad word about anybody
lines.name: English

lines.value: langdon gilkey who also survived the camp and became a prominent theologian in his native america said of liddell often in an evening i would see him bent over a chessboard or a model boat or directing some sort of square dance - absorbed weary and interested pouring all of himself into this effort to capture the imagination of these penned up youths
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was overflowing with good humour and love for life and with enthusiasm and charm
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is rare indeed that a person has the good fortune to meet a saint but he came as close to it as anyone i have ever known
lines.name: English

lines.value: in his last letter to his wife written on the day he died liddell wrote of suffering a nervous breakdown due to overwork
lines.name: English

lines.value: he actually had an inoperable brain tumour overwork and malnourishment may have hastened his death
lines.name: English

lines.value: liddell died on 21 february 1945 five months before liberation
lines.name: English

lines.value: langdon gilkey later wrote the entire camp especially its youth was stunned for days so great was the vacuum that eric's death had left according to a fellow missionary liddell's last words were it's complete surrender in reference to how he had given his life to god
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 5 june 1945 the eric liddell memorial committee was set up in glasgow seeking donations for a fund to provide for the education and maintenance of eric liddell's three daughters to fund an eric liddell missionary scholarship at the university of edinburgh and an eric liddell challenge trophy for amateur athletics and to erect a memorial in north china to commemorate eric liddell's work there
lines.name: English

lines.value: only the first and third objectives were achieved
lines.name: English

lines.value: to raise funds and to widen its appeal the committee published a pamphlet by dp thomson eric liddell the making of an athlete and the training of a missionary
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fund was eventually wound up in 1954 having raised £3687 15s over £88000 in relative purchasing power
lines.name: English

lines.value: dp thomson also spoke at well attended memorial services held in both edinburgh and glasgow in 1945
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2008 just before the beijing olympics chinese authorities claimed that liddell had refused an opportunity to leave the camp and instead gave his place to a pregnant woman
lines.name: English

lines.value: apparently the japanese and british with churchill's approval had agreed upon a prisoner exchange
lines.name: English

lines.value: however none of his friends or those who had lived with him in the camp gave the story any credence
lines.name: English

lines.value: 56 years after the 1924 paris olympics scotsman allan wells won the 100 metre sprint at the 1980 moscow olympics
lines.name: English

lines.value: when asked after the victory if he had run the race for harold abrahams the last 100 metre olympic winner from britain in 1924 who had died two years previously wells replied no i would prefer to dedicate this to eric liddell
lines.name: English

lines.value: eric liddell was the most popular athlete scotland has ever produced according to the public voting for the first inductees for the scottish sports hall of fame in 2002
lines.name: English

lines.value: liddell was buried in the garden behind the japanese officers quarters his grave marked by a small wooden cross
lines.name: English

lines.value: the site was forgotten until it was rediscovered in 1989 in the grounds of what is now weifeng middle school in shandong province north east china about six hours drive from beijing
lines.name: English

lines.value: its rediscovery was largely the result of the determination of charles walker an engineer working in hong kong who felt one of scotland's great heroes was in danger of being forgotten
lines.name: English

lines.value: his search for the grave proved difficult because since liddell's death place names had changed documents disappeared and witnesses were difficult to find
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1991 the university of edinburgh erected a memorial headstone made from isle of mull granite and carved by a mason in tobermory at the former camp site in weifang
lines.name: English

lines.value: the simple inscription came from the book of isaiah 40:31 they shall mount up with wings as eagles they shall run and not be weary the city of weifang commemorated liddell during the 60th anniversary of the internment camp's liberation by laying a wreath on his grave
lines.name: English

lines.value: the eric liddell centre was set up in edinburgh in 1980 to honour liddell's beliefs in community service whilst he lived and studied in edinburgh
lines.name: English

lines.value: local residents dedicated it to inspiring empowering and supporting people of all ages cultures and abilities as an expression of compassionate christian values
lines.name: English

lines.value: the liturgical calendar of the episcopal church usa remembers liddell with a feast day on 22 february
lines.name: English

lines.value: eltham college's sports centre was named eric liddell sports centre in his memory
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2012 the university of edinburgh launched a high performance sports scholarship named after liddell
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was announced during a visit by patricia russell liddell's oldest daughter
lines.name: English

lines.value: the 1981 film chariots of fire chronicles and contrasts the lives and viewpoints of liddell and harold abrahams
lines.name: English

lines.value: one inaccuracy surrounds liddell's refusal to race in the 100-metre event at the 1924 paris summer olympics
lines.name: English

lines.value: the film portrays liddell as finding out that one of the heats was to be held on a sunday as he boards the boat that will take the british olympic team across the english channel to paris
lines.name: English

lines.value: in reality the schedule and liddell's decision were both known several months in advance though his refusal to participate remains significant
lines.name: English

lines.value: liddell had also been selected to run as a member of the 4x100 and 4x400 relay teams at the olympics but also declined these spots as the finals were to be run on a sunday
lines.name: English

lines.value: one scene in the film depicts liddell falling early in a 440-yard race in a scotland france dual meet and making up a 20-yard deficit to win the actual race was during a triangular contest meet between scotland england and ireland at stoke on trent in england in july 1923
lines.name: English

lines.value: liddell was knocked to the ground several strides into the race
lines.name: English

lines.value: he hesitated got up and pursued his opponents 20 yards ahead
lines.name: English

lines.value: he caught the leaders shortly before the finish line and collapsed after crossing the tape
lines.name: English

lines.value: this scene was filmed at goldenacre stadium in edinburgh the playing fields of george heriot's school in edinburgh
lines.name: English

lines.value: producer david puttnam viewed footage from a 1924 film of liddell and abrahams while researching the film with scriptwriter colin welland and liddell's unorthodox running style as portrayed in the film with his head back and his mouth wide open is also said to be accurate
lines.name: English

lines.value: at an athletics championship in glasgow a visitor watching the 440 yard final in which liddell was a long way behind the leaders at the start of the last lap of a 220-yard track remarked to a glasgow native that liddell would be hard put to win the race
lines.name: English

lines.value: the glaswegian merely replied his head's no back yet liddell then threw his head back and with mouth wide open caught and passed his opponents to win the race
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1945 report of his death the guardian wrote he is remembered among lovers of athletics as probably the ugliest runner who ever won an olympic championship
lines.name: English

lines.value: when he appeared in the heats of the 400m at paris in 1924 his huge sprawling stride his head thrown back and his arms clawing the air moved the americans and other sophisticated experts to ribald laughter rival harold abrahams said in response to criticism of liddell's style people may shout their heads off about his appalling style
lines.name: English

lines.value: well let them
lines.name: English

lines.value: norman e doyle born november 11 1945 is a canadian businessman and politician in newfoundland and labrador
lines.name: English

lines.value: he is a current member of the senate of canada having been appointed in 2012
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also served as a member of the canadian house of commons from 1997 to 2008
lines.name: English

lines.value: doyle was a member of the newfoundland and labrador house of assembly from 1979 to 1993
lines.name: English

lines.value: he represented the provincial electoral district of harbour main sitting with the progressive conservative party of newfoundland and labrador
lines.name: English

lines.value: during his time in office he served multiple cabinet positions minister of communications from 1982 to 1984 than ran the municipal affairs portfolio from 1984 to 1987 and then transportation from 1987 to 1989 and finally as labour minister briefly in 1989
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was a conservative party of canada member of parliament in the canadian house of commons
lines.name: English

lines.value: he represented the riding of st john's east from 1997 to 2008
lines.name: English

lines.value: he has also been a member of the progressive conservative party of canada from 1997 till the party's merger in 2003 with the canadian alliance
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was formerly chair of the commons standing committee on citizenship and immigration
lines.name: English

lines.value: he served as the caucus chair of both the conservative party and the progressive conservative party
lines.name: English

lines.value: he served as the whip and deputy whip of the progressive conservative party and was critic of citizenship and immigration labour transport human resources development and human resources and skill development
lines.name: English

lines.value: doyle was appointed to the senate of canada to represent the province of newfoundland and labrador on january 6 2012 by governor general david johnston on the advice of prime minister stephen harper
lines.name: English

lines.value: he rejoined the conservative caucus with which he previously sat in the house of commons
lines.name: English

lines.value: an exit fare is a method of collecting ridership fees or fares from a transportation system where the fee or part of the fee is collected from passengers upon reaching their destination
lines.name: English

lines.value: exit fares were used on the subway lines of the early mbta in boston massachusetts as a cost cutting method to be able to collect increased fares without having to upgrade fare collection equipment at station entrances
lines.name: English

lines.value: the perceived unfairness of this system what to do with a passenger who can't pay the exit fare prompted boston politician walter a o'brien to commission the protest song m.t.a which later became a hit song by the kingston trio
lines.name: English

lines.value: the last of the subway exit fares were eliminated from the boston rail transit lines on december 4 2006 with the implementation of the charliecard
lines.name: English

lines.value: however some of the mbta's trackless trolley routes that use left side boarding in the harvard bus tunnel have exit fares because fares cannot be collected during boarding
lines.name: English

lines.value: in new york city this system is used on the airtrain at john f kennedy international airport
lines.name: English

lines.value: the system uses an exit fare to distinguish between intra airport trips which are free and connections to the subway and commuter rail which are not
lines.name: English

lines.value: the ind rockaway line charged a double fare south of howard beach station which entailed the deposit of two tokens for those entering along the line or one token on exit for those arriving from other parts of the system
lines.name: English

lines.value: the unpopular double fare was abolished in 1975
lines.name: English

lines.value: exit fares are also charged on the staten island railway at st george terminal and tompkinsville station because the primary function of the railway is to transport commuters on staten island to from the staten island ferry terminal at st george
lines.name: English

lines.value: commuters heading to manhattan via the ferry pay upon exiting the train at st george in the morning and upon entry at st george in the afternoon
lines.name: English

lines.value: exit fares are charged at tompkinsville because it is also within walking distance of the ferry terminal
lines.name: English

lines.value: before exit fares were charged at tompkinsville one could avoid paying the exit fare at st george by exiting at tompkinsville and walking to the ferry terminal
lines.name: English

lines.value: by charging entry and exit fares at st george and tompkinsville the other stations on the staten island railway can be run at far lower cost without any fare collection equipment or station employees present
lines.name: English

lines.value: on the washington metro riders process their farecards for both entering and exiting the system
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fare is actually deducted from the rider's card upon exiting the system based on the time of day and distance traveled
lines.name: English

lines.value: exitfare machines located near the fare gates allow riders to add additional value to their farecards should their cards lack sufficient value to exit the station at that location
lines.name: English

lines.value: bay area rapid transit also uses a similar fare collecting method based on distance but not time of day
lines.name: English

lines.value: on bart while ticket vendors outside the paid area accept credit and debit cards as well as cash the addfare machine which must be used if the ticket has insufficient value accepts cash only
lines.name: English

lines.value: this leads transit employees to ask that riders carrying only credit debit cards call a friend to bring cash to the station so that they may be allowed to exit
lines.name: English

lines.value: the port authority of allegheny county in pittsburgh pennsylvania uses exit fares to implement a free ride zone in downtown pittsburgh
lines.name: English

lines.value: riders going toward downtown and on routes that do not enter downtown pay on entry
lines.name: English

lines.value: riders leaving downtown pay on exit
lines.name: English

lines.value: riders traveling entirely within downtown do not pay at all
lines.name: English

lines.value: after 7 pm no free rides are provided downtown and all trips are charged a fare upon entry
lines.name: English

lines.value: metro transit in king county washington used a similar system until it was ended on september 29 2012
lines.name: English

lines.value: many lower volume point to point ticket based transit services use exit fares in one direction to avoid the expense of maintaining ticket offices at both ends of the line
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sokoto caliphate was an independent islamic caliphate in west africa
lines.name: English

lines.value: founded during the jihad of the fulani war in 1809 by usman dan fodio it was abolished when the british defeated the caliphate in 1903 and put the area under the northern nigeria protectorate
lines.name: English

lines.value: developed in the context of multiple independent hausa kingdoms at its height the caliphate linked over 30 different emirates and over 10 million people in the most powerful state in its region and one of the most significant empires in africa in the nineteenth century
lines.name: English

lines.value: the caliphate was a loose confederation of emirates that recognized the suzerainty of the commander of the faithful the sultan or caliph
lines.name: English

lines.value: the caliphate brought decades of economic growth throughout the region
lines.name: English

lines.value: an estimated one to 2.5 million non muslim slaves were captured during the fulani war
lines.name: English

lines.value: however slavery in the caliphate was not the more common chattel slavery slaves provided labor for plantations and were provided an opportunity to become muslims
lines.name: English

lines.value: although the british abolished the political authority of the caliphate the title of sultan was retained and remains an important religious position for muslims in the region to the current day
lines.name: English

lines.value: usman dan fodio's jihad provided the inspiration for a series of related jihads in other parts of the savanna and sahel far beyond nigeria's borders that led to the foundation of islamic states in senegal mali ivory coast chad central african republic and sudan
lines.name: English

lines.value: the major power in the region in the 17th and 18th centuries had been the bornu empire
lines.name: English

lines.value: however revolutions and the rise of new powers decreased the power of the bornu empire and by 1759 its rulers had lost control over the oasis town of bilma and access to the trans saharan trade
lines.name: English

lines.value: vassal cities of the empire gradually became autonomous and the result by 1780 was a political array of different independent states in the region
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fall of the songhai empire in 1598 had also freed much of the central bilad as sudan and a number of hausa sultanates led by different hausa aristocracies had grown to fill the void
lines.name: English

lines.value: three of the most significant to develop were the sultanates of gobir kebbi both in the rima river valley and zamfara all in present day nigeria
lines.name: English

lines.value: these kingdoms engaged in regular warfare against each other especially conducting slave raids and in order to pay for the constant warfare levied high taxation on their citizens
lines.name: English

lines.value: the region between the niger river and lake chad was largely populated with the hausa the fulani and other ethnic groups that had immigrated to the area
lines.name: English

lines.value: much of the hausa population had settled in the cities throughout the region
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fulani in contrast had largely remained a pastoral community herding cattle goats and sheep and populating grasslands between the towns throughout the region
lines.name: English

lines.value: with increasing trade a good number of fulani settled in towns forming a distinct minority
lines.name: English

lines.value: much of the population had converted to islam in the centuries before however nationalist and pagan beliefs persisted in many areas
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the end of the 1700s an increase in islamic preaching occurred throughout the hausa kingdoms
lines.name: English

lines.value: a number of the preachers were linked in a shared tariqa of islamic study
lines.name: English

lines.value: usman dan fodio an islamic scholar and an urbanized fulani had been actively educating and preaching in the city of gobir with the approval and support of the hausa leadership of the city
lines.name: English

lines.value: however when yunfa a former student of dan fodio became the sultan of gobir he restricted dan fodio's activities forcing him into exile in gudu
lines.name: English

lines.value: a large number of peoples left gobir to join dan fodio and as a response on february 21 1804 yunfa declared war on dan fodio
lines.name: English

lines.value: despite some early losses at the battle of tsuntua and elsewhere the forces of dan fodio began taking over some of the key cities starting in 1805
lines.name: English

lines.value: the war lasted from 1804 until 1808 and the forces of dan fodio were able to capture the states of katsina and daura and the important kingdom of kano in 1807 and gobir in 1808
lines.name: English

lines.value: the caliphate was founded in february 1804 at gudu when dan fodio was proclaimed amir al mu'minin defender of the faithful
lines.name: English

lines.value: usman dan fodio then declared a number of flag bearers amongst those following him creating an early political structure of the empire
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1809 muhammed bello the son of dan fodio founded the city of sokoto which became the capital of the sokoto caliphate
lines.name: English

lines.value: the jihads had created a new slaving frontier on the basis of rejuvenated islam by 1900 the sokoto caliphate had at least 1 million and perhaps as many as 2.5 million slaves second only to the american south which had four million in 1860 in size among all modern slave societies
lines.name: English

lines.value: however slavery in the caliphate just as in the rest of the muslim world did not take on the form of chattel slavery and there was far less of a distinction between slaves and their masters
lines.name: English

lines.value: from 1808 until the mid 1830s the sokoto caliphate expanded gradually annexing the plains to the west and key parts of yorubaland
lines.name: English

lines.value: it became one of the largest states in africa stretching from modern day burkina faso to cameroon and including most of northern nigeria and niger republic
lines.name: English

lines.value: at its height the sokoto caliphate included over 30 different emirates under its political structure
lines.name: English

lines.value: the political structure of the caliphate was organized with the sultan of sokoto ruling from the city of sokoto and for a brief period under muhammad bello from wurno
lines.name: English

lines.value: the leader of each emirate was appointed by the sultan as the flag bearer for that city but was given wide independence and autonomy
lines.name: English

lines.value: much of the growth of the caliphate occurred through the establishment of an extensive system of ribats as part of the consolidation policy of muhammed bello the second sultan
lines.name: English

lines.value: ribats were established founding a number of new cities with walled fortresses schools markets and other buildings
lines.name: English

lines.value: these proved crucial in expanding the caliphate by developing new cities settling the pastoral fulani people and supporting the growth of plantations which were crucial to the economy
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1837 the sokoto caliphate had a population around 10 million people
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sokoto caliphate was largely organized around a number of largely independent emirates pledging allegiance to the sultan of sokoto
lines.name: English

lines.value: the administration was initially built to follow those of muhammad during his time in medina but also the theories of al mawardi in the ordinances of government
lines.name: English

lines.value: the hausa kingdoms prior to the caliphate had been run largely through hereditary succession for leadership
lines.name: English

lines.value: the early rulers of the sokoto caliphate dan fodio and bello abolished systems of hereditary succession and preferred if leaders were appointed by virtue of their islamic scholarship and moral standing
lines.name: English

lines.value: emirs were appointed by the sultan they traveled yearly to deliver allegiance and taxes in the form of crops cowry shells and slaves
lines.name: English

lines.value: when a sultan died or retired from the office an appointment council made up of the emirs would select a replacement
lines.name: English

lines.value: direct lines of succession were largely not followed for sultan although each sultan claims direct descent from dan fodio
lines.name: English

lines.value: the major administrative division was between the sokoto caliphate and the gwandu emirate
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1815 usman dan fodio retired from the administrative business of the caliphate and divided the area taken over during the fulani war with his brother abdullahi dan fodio ruling in the west with the gwandu emirate and his son muhammed bello taking over administration of the sokoto caliphate
lines.name: English

lines.value: the emir at gwandu retained allegiance to the sokoto caliphate and spiritual guidance from the sultan but the emir managed the separate emirates under his supervision independently from the sultan
lines.name: English

lines.value: the administrative structure of loose allegiances of the emirates to the sultan did not always function smoothly
lines.name: English

lines.value: there was a series of revolutions by hausa aristocracy in 1816 1817 during the reign of muhammed bello but the sultan ended these by granting those members title to land
lines.name: English

lines.value: there were multiple crises that arose during the century between the sokoto caliphate and many of the emirates notably the adamawa emirate and the kano emirate
lines.name: English

lines.value: a serious revolt occurred in 1836 in the city state of gobir which was crushed by muhammed bello at the battle of gawakuke
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sufi community throughout the region proved crucial in the administration of the caliphate
lines.name: English

lines.value: the tariqa brotherhoods notably the qadiriyya to which every successive sultan of sokoto was an adherent provided a group linking the distinct emirates to the authority of the sultan
lines.name: English

lines.value: scholars burnham and last claim that this islamic scholarship community provided an embryonic bureaucracy which linked the cities throughout the caliphate
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the establishment of the caliphate there were decades of economic growth throughout the region particularly after a wave of revolts in 1816 1817
lines.name: English

lines.value: they had significant trade over the trans saharan routes
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the fulani war all land in the empire was declared waqf or owned by the entire community
lines.name: English

lines.value: however the sultan allocated land to individuals or families as could an emir
lines.name: English

lines.value: such land could be inherited by family members but could not be sold
lines.name: English

lines.value: exchange was based largely on slaves cowries or gold
lines.name: English

lines.value: major crops produced included cotton indigo kola and shea nuts grain rice tobacco and onion
lines.name: English

lines.value: slavery remained a large part of the economy although its operation had changed with the end of the atlantic slave trade
lines.name: English

lines.value: slaves were gained through raiding and via markets as had operated earlier in west africa
lines.name: English

lines.value: the founder of the caliphate allowed slavery only for non muslims slavery was viewed as a process to bring such peoples into the muslim community
lines.name: English

lines.value: the expansion of agricultural plantations under the caliphate was dependent on slave labor however
lines.name: English

lines.value: these plantations were established around the ribats and large areas of agricultural production took place around the cities of the empire
lines.name: English

lines.value: the institution of slavery was mediated by the lack of a racial barrier among the peoples and by a complex and varying set of relations between owners and slaves which included the right to accumulate property by working on their own plots manumission and the potential for slaves to convert and become members of the islamic community
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are historical records of slaves reaching high levels of government and administration in the sokoto caliphate
lines.name: English

lines.value: its commercial prosperity was also based on islamist traditions market integration internal peace and an extensive export trade network
lines.name: English

lines.value: islamic scholarship was a crucial aspect of the caliphate from its founding
lines.name: English

lines.value: sultan usman dan fodio sultan muhammed bello emir abdullahi dan fodio sultan abu bakr atiku and nana asma'u devoted significant time to chronicling histories writing poetry and islamic studies
lines.name: English

lines.value: a number of manuscripts are available and they provide crucial historical information and important spiritual texts
lines.name: English

lines.value: this role did diminish after the reign of bello and atiku
lines.name: English

lines.value: european attention had been focusing on the region for colonial expansion for much of the last part of the 19th century
lines.name: English

lines.value: the french in particular had sent multiple exploratory missions to the area to assess colonial opportunities after 1870
lines.name: English

lines.value: french explorer parfait louis monteil visited sokoto in 1891 and noted that the caliphate was at war with the emir of argungu defeating argungu the next year
lines.name: English

lines.value: monteil claimed that fulani power was tottering because of the war and the accession of the unpopular caliph abderrahman dan abi bakar
lines.name: English

lines.value: however following the berlin conference the british had expanded into southern nigeria and by 1902 had begun plans to move into the sokoto caliphate
lines.name: English

lines.value: british general frederick lugard used rivalries between many of the emirs in the south and the central sokoto administration to prevent any defense as he worked toward the capital
lines.name: English

lines.value: as the british approached the city of sokoto the new sultan muhammadu attahiru i organized a quick defense of the city and fought the advancing british led forces
lines.name: English

lines.value: the british force quickly won sending attahiru i and thousands of followers on a mahdist hijra
lines.name: English

lines.value: on march 13 1903 at the grand market square of sokoto the last vizier of the caliphate officially conceded to british rule
lines.name: English

lines.value: the british appointed muhammadu attahiru ii as the new caliph
lines.name: English

lines.value: fredrick lugard abolished the caliphate but retained the title sultan as a symbolic position in the newly organized northern nigeria protectorate
lines.name: English

lines.value: in june 1903 the british defeated the remaining forces of attahiru i and killed him by 1906 resistance to british rule had ended
lines.name: English

lines.value: the canada games () is a high level multi sport event formerly with a national artists program held every two years in canada alternating between the canada winter games and the canada summer games
lines.name: English

lines.value: athletes are strictly amateur only and represent their province or territory
lines.name: English

lines.value: the games were first held in 1967 in quebec city as part of canada's centennial celebrations
lines.name: English

lines.value: for the first time in canada's history 1800 athletes from 10 provinces and two territories gathered to compete in 15 sports
lines.name: English

lines.value: under the games motto unity through sport these first canada winter games paved the way to what is now canada's largest multi sport competition for young athletes
lines.name: English

lines.value: the governing body for the canada games is the canada games council a non profit private organization incorporated in 1991
lines.name: English

lines.value: the individual games are run by the local host society a non profit private organization created for the purpose in accordance with an agreement between the local host society the government of canada the government of the province or territory the government of the municipality and the canada games council
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example the 2011 halifax games were run by the halifax 2011 canada games host society on the basis of an agreement between the host society and the canada games council canada nova scotia and the city of halifax
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2015 for the first time there was also a local host first nation lheidli t'enneh
lines.name: English

lines.value: funding for the games comes from the several levels of government together with donations and corporate sponsorships
lines.name: English

lines.value: a considerable portion of the work during the games is performed by local volunteers
lines.name: English

lines.value: held every two years alternating between summer and winter the canada games are a key event in the development of canada's young athletes
lines.name: English

lines.value: as the best in their age group these young competitors come to the games having trained long and hard to be among those chosen to represent their respective province or territory and compete for the canada games flag and centennial cup
lines.name: English

lines.value: with the canada games poised as a key step in the development of canada's future stars canada games athletes are canada's next generation national international and olympic champions
lines.name: English

lines.value: the canada games and their lasting legacies continue to be the catalyst for the growth of sport and recreation across canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: since 1967 over 75000 athletes have participated in the games with hundreds of thousands having engaged in try outs and qualifying events
lines.name: English

lines.value: over 100000 coaches officials and volunteers have been directly involved in the planning and staging of the games
lines.name: English

lines.value: cumulatively $250 million has been invested in the canada games about half of it in capital projects in the various host communities
lines.name: English

lines.value: from the saint john canada games aquatic centre 1985 to the hillside stadium and aquatic centre in kamloops bc 1993 from the corner brook canada games centre and annex 1999 to the td waterhouse stadium in london ontario 2001 a legacy of sports facilities has been built in over 16 communities across canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: the canada games a celebration of youth sport culture and community are the product of ongoing collaboration between the government of canada provincial territorial governments host municipalities the private sector and the canada games council
lines.name: English

lines.value: the 2009 canada summer games were hosted by the entire province of prince edward island
lines.name: English

lines.value: the most recent games took place in winnipeg manitoba between july 28 and august 13 2017
lines.name: English

lines.value: since their inception in 1967 the canada games have played a prominent role in developing some of canada's premier athletes
lines.name: English

lines.value: the games have acted as a stepping stone for many of canada's celebrated athletes
lines.name: English

lines.value: the canada games council is the governing body for the canada games
lines.name: English

lines.value: as the games move from one host community to the next the council provides the continuity leadership and support to host societies in key areas such as sport technical organizational planning ceremonies and protocol marketing and sponsorship
lines.name: English

lines.value: * the host cities have not been chosen for the games after 2021 but the provinces through 2035 have
lines.name: English

lines.name: English

lines.value: scanning voltage microscopy svm sometimes also called nanopotentiometry is a scientific experimental technique based on atomic force microscopy
lines.name: English

lines.value: a conductive probe usually only a few nanometers wide at the tip is placed in full contact with an operational electronic or optoelectronic sample
lines.name: English

lines.value: by connecting the probe to a high impedance voltmeter and rastering over the sample's surface a map of the electric potential can be acquired
lines.name: English

lines.value: svm is generally nondestructive to the sample although some damage may occur to the sample or the probe if the pressure required to maintain good electrical contact is too high
lines.name: English

lines.value: if the input impedance of the voltmeter is sufficiently large the svm probe should not perturb the operation of the operational sample
lines.name: English

lines.value: svm is particularly well suited to analyzing microelectronic devices such as transistors or diodes or quantum electronic devices such as quantum well diode lasers directly because nanometer spatial resolution is possible
lines.name: English

lines.value: svm can also be used to verify theoretical simulation of complex electronic devices
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example the potential profile across the quantum well structure of a diode laser can be mapped and analyzed such a profile could indicate the electron and hole distributions where light is generated and could lead to improved laser designs
lines.name: English

lines.value: in a similar technique scanning gate microscopy sgm the probe is oscillated at some natural frequency some fixed distance above the sample with an applied voltage relative to the sample
lines.name: English

lines.value: the image is constructed from the x,y position of the probe and the conductance of the sample with no significant current passing through the probe which acts as a local gate
lines.name: English

lines.value: the image is interpreted as a map of the sample's sensitivity to gate voltage
lines.name: English

lines.value: a lock in amplifier aids noise reduction by filtering through only the amplitude oscillations that match the probe's vibration frequency
lines.name: English

lines.value: applications include imaging defect sites in carbon nanotubes and doping profiles in nanowires
lines.name: English

lines.value: sopron german odenburg was an administrative county comitatus of the kingdom of hungary in present day eastern austria and northwestern hungary
lines.name: English

lines.value: the capital of the county was sopron
lines.name: English

lines.value: sopron county shared borders with the austrian land lower austria and the hungarian counties moson gyor veszprem and vas
lines.name: English

lines.value: the lake neusiedl hungarian ferto to german neusiedler see lied in the county
lines.name: English

lines.value: its area was 3241 km² around 1910
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sopron comitatus arose as one of the first comitatus of the kingdom of hungary
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1920 by the treaty of trianon the western part of the county became part of the austrian state of burgenland while the eastern part became a part of hungary
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1921 it was decided by referendum that the city of sopron would join hungary instead of austria
lines.name: English

lines.value: after world war ii sopron county merged with gyor-moson-pozsony to form gyor-sopron county
lines.name: English

lines.value: this county was renamed to gyor-moson-sopron county in the early 1990s
lines.name: English

lines.value: a small part of sopron county went to vas county
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1900 the county had a population of 279796 people and was composed of the following linguistic communities total total
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1910 the county had a population of 283510 people and was composed of the following linguistic communities total total
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the early 20th century the subdivisions of sopron county were eisenstadt mattersburg rust and oberpullendorf are now in austria
lines.name: English

lines.value: music is a part of the warp and weft of the fabric of nova scotia's cultural life
lines.name: English

lines.value: this deep and lasting love of music is expressed through the performance and enjoyment of all types and genres of music
lines.name: English

lines.value: while popular music from many genres has experienced almost two decades of explosive growth and success in nova scotia the province remains best known for its folk and traditional based music
lines.name: English

lines.value: nova scotia's folk music is characteristically scottish in character and traditions from scotland are kept very traditional in form in some cases more so than in scotland
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is especially true of the island of cape breton one of the major international centres for celtic music
lines.name: English

lines.value: nova scotia is one of three canadian maritime provinces or simply the maritimes
lines.name: English

lines.value: when combined with newfoundland and labrador the region is known as the atlantic provinces or atlantic canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: despite the small population of the province nova scotia's music and culture is influenced by several well established cultural groups that are sometimes referred to as the founding cultures originally populated by the mi'kmaq first nation the first european settlers were the french who founded acadia in 1604
lines.name: English

lines.value: nova scotia was briefly colonized by scottish settlers in 1620 though by 1624 the scottish settlers had been removed by treaty and the area was turned over to the french until the mid 18th century
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the defeat of the french and prior expulsion of the acadians settlers of english irish scottish and african descent began arriving on the shores of nova scotia
lines.name: English

lines.value: settlement was greatly accelerated by the resettlement of loyalists called in canada united empire loyalists in nova scotia during the period following the end of the american revolutionary war
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was during this time that a large african nova scotian community took root populated by freed slaves and black loyalists and their families who had fought for the crown in exchange for land
lines.name: English

lines.value: this community later grew when the royal navy began intercepting slave ships destined for the united states and deposited these free slaves on the shores of nova scotia
lines.name: English

lines.value: later in the 19th century the irish great hunger and scottish highland clearances resulted in large influxes of migrants with celtic cultural roots which helped to define the dominantly celtic character of cape breton and the north mainland of the province
lines.name: English

lines.value: this celtic or gaelic culture was so pervasive that at the outset of world war i reporters from london england were horrified when some of the first regiments to arrive in england from canada piped themselves ashore styled themselves as highland regiments and spoke scottish gaelic as their primary language
lines.name: English

lines.value: scottish traditional music has remained vibrant on cape breton into the 21st century and has produced several performers of international renown
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first major musician from the island was rita macneil a mainstream singer whose music did not draw deeply on celtic traditions
lines.name: English

lines.value: she was followed by stan rogers who was born in ontario to a nova scotian family and sang ballads of seagoing maritimers though again little reflecting the area's scottish traditions
lines.name: English

lines.value: the province is the heart of a vibrant and popular style of celtic music and dance derived from the influence of its highland scottish settlement concentrated especially on cape breton island
lines.name: English

lines.value: the basic duo of fiddle and piano provide a strongly accented dance music in small town church and community halls
lines.name: English

lines.value: sometimes a guitar is augmented and highland bagpipe music is also popular
lines.name: English

lines.value: in many ways the music and dance over two centuries of relative physical isolation provides a snapshot of scottish music and dance as it was before its european base took other more refined routes and today cape breton fiddle music has taken a place as a major attraction at celtic cultural festivals
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first popular musician who showed nova scotia's celtic heritage to the mainstream world was john allan cameron a singer and guitarist and son of legendary fiddler katie ann cameron who was herself the sister of the music collector dan rory macdonald
lines.name: English

lines.value: more recent performers with a celtic sound in their music include the pop crooning of sarah mclachlan from halifax mary jane lamond and flautist chris norman
lines.name: English

lines.value: cape breton has a well known bagpipe tradition and has produced some well known pipers including angus macdonald barry shears and jamie macinnes
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is however the fiddling tradition which nova scotia and cape breton is best known for and the biggest name in this tradition is winston scotty fitzgerald from cape breton
lines.name: English

lines.value: also of his generation were a litany of names now known in the international scene though renown came late for most these include joe maclean bill lamey buddy macmaster alex francis mackay dan joe macinnes angus chisholm dan hughie maceachern donald angus beaton theresa maclellan joe cormier and paddy leblanc
lines.name: English

lines.value: many of these were first given distribution outside of the area by american folk label rounder records which began a cape breton unit in the early 1970s
lines.name: English

lines.value: the rankin family did more than any group to bring cape breton folk music to mainstream audiences in canada and abroad
lines.name: English

lines.value: they had performed as a family since childhood playing traditional music that gradually became more modern as their fame grew
lines.name: English

lines.value: perhaps the most well known modern cape breton fiddler is natalie macmaster who comes from a line of musicians that includes buddy macmaster wendy macisaac and ashley macisaac
lines.name: English

lines.value: her cousin ashley macisaac is notable for having achieved success playing both traditional music and radical musical fusions exemplified by his hi™ how are you today
lines.name: English

lines.value: 1995 a landmark recording
lines.name: English

lines.value: to the south of cape breton on the north mainland due to the many irish settlements irish influenced traditional music is often heard in the rural villages of guysborough county and antigonish county
lines.name: English

lines.value: although fiddle and singing are popular it is not uncommon to hear an accordion often locally referred to as a squeezebox
lines.name: English

lines.value: spoons guitars and sometimes a bodhran are also used for rhythmic drive
lines.name: English

lines.value: despite the dominance of traditional based music both as a form of cultural expression and as a means to brand the tourism experience for visitors to nova scotia the province also has a long history of producing successful popular music acts
lines.name: English

lines.value: many notable internationally known artists are from nova scotia in a wide variety of genres
lines.name: English

lines.value: as early as the 1930s the music of nova scotia was entertaining the world
lines.name: English

lines.value: hank snow born and raised in brooklyn queen's county nova scotia was signed to rca records in 1936 but became famous in 1950 when he was invited to appear at the grand ole opry
lines.name: English

lines.value: that was also the year he released i'm moving on his first massive hit single
lines.name: English

lines.value: portia white of truro nova scotia one of the greatest contralto voices in the history of canadian classical music made her stage debut in 1941
lines.name: English

lines.value: white went on to become an internationally known and respected performer
lines.name: English

lines.value: an early introduction of the music often referred to as the fifties revolution came from halifax musician and entertainer eddy m melanson
lines.name: English

lines.value: eddy made his debut in 1953 performing for the halifax coloured citizens improvement league at the odeon theatre with a revised upbeat country sound.that sound was later classified by music historian steve fruitman as a reincarnation of the country jump blues.eddy formed his own band in the mid fifties and named it the rockabillys placing him at the beginning of that genre of music introducing it in nova scotia
lines.name: English

lines.value: when bill haley and the comets toured in the maritimes in 1958 eddy and his rockabillys was selected as the canadian group to open and close for them
lines.name: English

lines.value: he's inducted into the rockabilly hall of fame #381 as an original canadian rockabilly
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1966 the men of the deeps the coal miners of cape breton began and tour all over north america to this day
lines.name: English

lines.value: the pop and country sounds of the 1970s were exemplified by springhill nova scotia native anne murray and her haligonian producer brian ahern
lines.name: English

lines.value: she had a series of top 10 hits worldwide starting with snowbird in 1970 and continues to be a major concert performer
lines.name: English

lines.value: anne murray had a 1 billboard hot 100 hit with the country pop you needed me in 1978
lines.name: English

lines.value: possibly the most famous rock band from the 1970s was progressive rockers april wine but other bands such as pepper tree dutch mason matt minglewood and stan crawford band which became the jetz enjoyed a great degree of national and international success
lines.name: English

lines.value: as the music scene in nova scotia started to coalesce around halifax and its emerging underground scene new sounds and new styles of music started to be heard
lines.name: English

lines.value: both the punk and new wave movements found fertile ground in halifax the latter producing a band whose lead singer sarah mclachlan would be snapped up in the 1980s and moved to vancouver to later become a huge international star
lines.name: English

lines.value: sarah mclachlan had 2 2 albums on the billboard 200 like the adult contemporary surfacing in 1997
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was toward the end of the 1980s that the music scene in nova scotia seemed to truly become an industry with nova scotians leading the creation of the east coast music awards as well as establishing the music industry association of nova scotia
lines.name: English

lines.value: performers as diverse as rock band blackpool hip hop artists mc g and cool j and celtic pop darlings the rankin family all achieved national radio & video play major label record deals and national media recognition
lines.name: English

lines.value: this was followed by the halifax music explosion of the 1990s which saw bands such as sloan eric's trip jale thrush hermit and newfoundland emigres the hardship post obtain international recognition and recording deals with labels such as dgc and sub pop
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was during this time that the internationally known halifax pop explosion music festival was founded in 1993
lines.name: English

lines.value: though the initial excitement generated during this time has abated nova scotia remains at the forefront of the internationally successful canadian music wave with artists who came out of that era such as joel plaskett and hip hop hero buck 65 continuing to gain worldwide respect and attention
lines.name: English

lines.value: other acts such as the trews the stanfields matt mays and jimmy swift band have all experienced considerable success nationally
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the past decade a number of independent record labels have emerged to support the growth of the indie rock
lines.name: English

lines.value: dependent music publishes music by popular acts such as wintersleep brian borcherdt jill barber and holy fuck
lines.name: English

lines.value: belowmemusic promotes the jimmy swift band slowcoaster and grand theft bus
lines.name: English

lines.value: while historically isolated from the toronto centric canadian hip hop scene nova scotia has an increasing number of nationally known acts
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1980s bands such as down by law mc g and cool j and hip club groove experienced degrees of national success
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1990s and early 21st century many artists have achieved national success
lines.name: English

lines.value: buck 65 from mount uniacke has released several well received records internationally
lines.name: English

lines.value: sixtoo is signed to and released several records on montreal label ninjatune
lines.name: English

lines.value: universal soul have seen considerable national exposure since being nominated for two muchmusic video awards in 2003
lines.name: English

lines.value: classified is an mc and producer nominated for a 2004 cuma
lines.name: English

lines.value: the goods with members kunga 219 and gordski have successfully toured across north america
lines.name: English

lines.value: kaleb simmonds achieved a national reputation after a showing in the top ten on the first season of canadian idol
lines.name: English

lines.value: scratch bastid came in second in the 2004 canadian dmc finals in winnipeg and won the 2004 scribble jam in cincinnati
lines.name: English

lines.value: dj iv dj lap one and y rush are some of the city's current hip hop djs who mix using old school contemporary and underground hip hop
lines.name: English

lines.value: air marshal sir richard williams 3 august 18907 february 1980 is widely regarded as the father of the royal australian air force raaf
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was the first military pilot trained in australia and went on to command australian and british fighter units in world war i a proponent for air power independent of other branches of the armed services williams played a leading role in the establishment of the raaf and became its first chief of the air staff cas in 1922
lines.name: English

lines.value: he served as cas for thirteen years over three terms longer than any other officer
lines.name: English

lines.value: williams came from a working class background in south australia
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was a lieutenant in the army when he learned to fly at point cook victoria in 1914
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a pilot with the australian flying corps afc in world war i williams rose to command no
lines.name: English

lines.value: 1 squadron afc and later 40th wing raf
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was awarded the distinguished service order and finished the war a lieutenant colonel
lines.name: English

lines.value: afterwards he campaigned for an australian air force run separately to the army and navy which came into being on 31 march 1921
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fledgling raaf faced several challenges to its continued existence in the 1920s and early 1930s and williams received much of the credit for maintaining its independence
lines.name: English

lines.value: however an adverse report on flying safety standards saw him dismissed from the position of cas and seconded to the raf prior to world war ii
lines.name: English

lines.value: despite support in various quarters for his reinstatement as air force chief and promotion to air marshal in 1940 he never again commanded the raaf
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the war he was forcibly retired along with other world war i veteran officers
lines.name: English

lines.value: he took up the position of director general of civil aviation in australia and was knighted the year before his retirement in 1955
lines.name: English

lines.value: williams was born on 3 august 1890 into a working class family in moonta mines south australia
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was the eldest son of richard williams a copper miner who had emigrated from cornwall england and his wife emily
lines.name: English

lines.value: leaving moonta public school at junior secondary level williams worked as a telegraph messenger and later as a bank clerk
lines.name: English

lines.value: he enlisted in a militia unit the south australian infantry regiment in 1909 at the age of nineteen
lines.name: English

lines.value: commissioned a second lieutenant on 8 march 1911 he joined the permanent military forces the following year
lines.name: English

lines.value: in august 1914 lieutenant williams took part in australia's inaugural military flying course at central flying school run by lieutenants henry petre and eric harrison
lines.name: English

lines.value: after soloing in a bristol boxkite around the airfield at point cook victoria williams became the first student to graduate as a pilot on 12 november 1914
lines.name: English

lines.value: he recalled the school as a ragtime show consisting of a paddock tents and one large structure a shed for the boxkite
lines.name: English

lines.value: following an administrative and instructional posting williams underwent advanced flying training at point cook in july 1915
lines.name: English

lines.value: the next month he married constance esther griffiths who was thirteen years his senior
lines.name: English

lines.value: the couple had no children
lines.name: English

lines.value: williams was promoted captain on 5 january 1916
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was appointed a flight commander in no
lines.name: English

lines.value: 1 squadron australian flying corps afc which was initially numbered 67 squadron royal flying corps by the british
lines.name: English

lines.value: the unit departed australia in march 1916 without any aircraft after arriving in egypt it received b.e.2 fighters a type deficient in speed and manoeuvrability and which lacked forward firing machine guns
lines.name: English

lines.value: williams wrote that in combat with the german fokkers our fighting in the air was of short duration but could mean a quick end and that when it came to bombing he and his fellow pilots depended mainly on luck
lines.name: English

lines.value: now for the first time wrote williams after 17 months in the field we had aircraft with which we could deal with our enemy in the air his men knew him as a teetotaller and non smoker whose idea of swearing was an occasional darn me

lines.name: English

lines.value: augmented by a giant handley page bomber his forces took part in the battle of armageddon the final offensive in palestine where they inflicted wholesale destruction on turkish columns
lines.name: English

lines.value: of 40th wing's actions at wadi fara on 21 september 1918 williams wrote the turkish seventh army ceased to exist and it must be noted that this was entirely the result of attack from the air he also sent captain ross smith in the handley page accompanied by two bristol fighters to aid major t e lawrence's arab army north of amman when it was harassed by german aircraft operating from deraa

lines.value: his service in the theatre later saw him awarded the order of the nahda by the king of the hejaz
lines.name: English

lines.value: twice mentioned in despatches by the end of the war williams had established himself in the words of raaf historian alan stephens as the afc's rising star
lines.name: English

lines.value: appointed an officer of the order of the british empire in the 1919 new year honours williams served as staff officer aviation at australian imperial force aif headquarters in london before returning to australia and taking up the position of director of air services at army headquarters melbourne
lines.name: English

lines.value: the australian flying corps had meanwhile been disbanded and replaced by the australian air corps aac which was like the afc a branch of the army
lines.name: English

lines.value: upon establishment of the australian air board on 9 november 1920 williams and his fellow aac officers dropped their army ranks in favour of those based on the royal air force
lines.name: English

lines.value: williams now a wing commander personally compiled and tabled the air board's submissions to create the australian air force aaf a service independent of both the army and the royal australian navy
lines.name: English

lines.value: though the heads of the army and navy opposed the creation of an independent air arm for fear that they would be unable to find air cover for their operations support from prime minister billy hughes as well as prominent parliamentary figures including treasurer joseph cook and defence minister george pearce allowed the proposal to succeed
lines.name: English

lines.value: the aaf was duly formed on 31 march 1921 williams deliberately chose this day rather than 1 april the founding date of the raf three years earlier to prevent nasty people referring to us as april fools
lines.name: English

lines.value: the royal prefix was added five months later
lines.name: English

lines.value: williams proposed an ensign for the aaf in july 1921 based on the royal air force flag but featuring the five stars of the southern cross within the raf roundel and the commonwealth star in the lower hoist quarter
lines.name: English

lines.value: this design was not adopted for the raaf the government employing instead a direct copy of the raf ensign until 1949 when a new design using the stars of the australian flag was chosen
lines.name: English

lines.value: as the senior officer of the air board williams held the title of first air member the nascent air force initially not being deemed suitable for a chief of staff appointment equivalent to the army and navy
lines.name: English

lines.value: he moved to consolidate the new service's position by expanding its assets and training
lines.name: English

lines.value: shortly after the aaf's establishment land was purchased for an air base at laverton eight kilometres five miles inland of point cook and in july 1921 williams made the initial proposal to develop a base at richmond new south wales the first outside victoria
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also started a program to second students from the army and navy including graduates of the royal military college duntroon to bolster officer numbers candidates reaped by this scheme included future air force chiefs john mccauley frederick scherger valston hancock and alister murdoch along with other senior identities such as joe hewitt and frank bladin
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a leader williams would gain a reputation for strong will absorption in administrative minutiae and a somewhat puritanical nature
lines.name: English

lines.value: he became known throughout the service as dicky
lines.name: English

lines.value: the position of first air member was replaced by chief of the air staff cas in october 1922
lines.name: English

lines.value: williams would serve as cas three times over seventeen years in the 1920s and 30s alternating with wing commander later air vice marshal stanley goble
lines.name: English

lines.value: one motive suggested for the rotation was a ploy by army and navy interests to curb williams independence
lines.name: English

lines.value: instead the arrangement almost inevitably fostered an unproductive rivalry between the two officers
lines.name: English

lines.value: although in a legal sense the air board was responsible for the raaf rather than the chief of staff alone williams dominated the board to such an extent that goble would later complain that his colleague appeared to consider the air force his personal command
lines.name: English

lines.value: williams spent much of 1923 in england attending the british army staff college in camberley and raf staff college andover followed by further study in canada and the united states the following year
lines.name: English

lines.value: goble served as chief of the air staff in his absence
lines.name: English

lines.value: shortly after his return in february 1925 williams scuppered a plan by goble to establish a small seaplane base at rushcutters bay in sydney instead organising purchase of supermarine seagulls the raaf's first amphibious aircraft to be based at richmond
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was promoted to group captain in july and later that year drafted a major air warfare study memorandum regarding the air defence of australia
lines.name: English

lines.value: considered prescient in many ways it treated world war i ally japan as australia's main military threat and advocated inter service co operation while maintaining that none of the armed forces was purely auxiliary to another
lines.name: English

lines.value: its concepts continue to influence raaf strategy
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1926 williams mandated the use of parachutes for all raaf aircrew
lines.name: English

lines.value: he had visited the irvin air chute company while in the us during 1924 and recommended purchase at the time but a backlog of orders for the raf meant that the australian equipment took almost two years to arrive
lines.name: English

lines.value: flying officer ellis wackett was assigned to instruct volunteers at raaf richmond and made the country's first freefall descent from a military aircraft an airco dh.9 on 26 may
lines.name: English

lines.value: williams himself jumped over point cook on 5 august having decided that it would set a good example if before issuing an order for the compulsory wearing of parachutes i showed my own confidence in them " though his descent took him perilously close to the base water tank i thought it would be a poor ending to drown there or even to be pulled out dripping wet and too close to be comfortable to a 30000 volt electric transmission line he completed the exercise unscathed
lines.name: English

lines.value: the young air force was a small organisation with the atmosphere of a flying club although several pioneering flights were made by its members
lines.name: English

lines.value: goble had commanded the first circumnavigation of australia by air in 1924 while he was cas
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 25 september 1926 with two crew members including goble's pilot ivor mcintyre williams commenced a round trip from point cook to the solomon islands in a de havilland dh.50a floatplane to study the south pacific region as a possible theatre of operations
lines.name: English

lines.value: the trio returned on 7 december to a 12-plane raaf escort and a 300-man honour guard
lines.name: English

lines.value: though seen partly as a matter of prestige brought on by contemporary newspaper reports that claimed certain foreign powers were planning such a journey and also as a reaction by williams to goble's 1924 expedition it was notable as the first international flight undertaken by an raaf plane and crew
lines.name: English

lines.value: williams was appointed a commander of the order of the british empire cbe in the 1927 king's birthday honours in recognition of the achievement and promoted to air commodore on 1 july the same year
lines.name: English

lines.value: as cas williams had to contend with serious challenges to the raaf's continued existence from the army and navy in 1929 and 1932 arising from the competing demands for defence funding during the great depression
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to williams only after 1932 was the independence of the air force assured
lines.name: English

lines.value: williams again handed over the reins of cas to goble in 1933 to attend the imperial defence college in london resuming his position in june 1934
lines.name: English

lines.value: his promotion to air vice marshal on 1 january 1935 belatedly raised him to the equivalent rank of his fellow chiefs of staff in the army and navy
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was appointed a companion of the order of the bath in june that year
lines.name: English

lines.value: williams encouraged the local aircraft industry as a means to further the self sufficiency of the air force and australian aviation in general

lines.value: he played a personal part in the creation of the commonwealth aircraft corporation in november 1936 headed up by former squadron leader lawrence wackett late of the raaf's experimental section
lines.name: English

lines.value: williams made the first overseas flight in an aeroplane designed and built in australia when he accompanied squadron leader allan walters and two aircrew aboard a tugan gannet to singapore in february 1938

lines.value: a series of mishaps with hawker demons at the end of 1937 which resulted in one pilot dying and four injured subjected the air force to harsh public criticism

lines.value: in 1939 williams was dismissed from his post as cas and effectively banished overseas following publication of the ellington report that january

lines.value: its author marshal of the royal air force sir edward leonard ellington criticised the level of air safety observed in the raaf though his interpretation of statistics has been called into question
lines.name: English

lines.value: the federal government praised williams for strengthening the air force but blamed him for ellington's findings and he was criticised in the press

lines.value: beyond the adverse report williams was thought to have made enemies through his strident championing of the raaf's independence
lines.name: English

lines.value: a later cas george jones contended that ellington had been invited to australia in order to inspect williams rather than the air force and to recommend his removal from the post of chief of the air staff if necessary

lines.value: the government announced that it was seconding him to the raf for two years

lines.value: when war broke out in september 1939 williams was air officer in charge of administration at raf coastal command a position he had held since february that year following a brief posting to the british air ministry
lines.name: English

lines.value: goble had succeeded williams as chief of the air staff for the last time but clashed with the federal government over implementation of the empire air training scheme and stepped down in early 1940

lines.value: williams was recalled from britain with the expectation of again taking up the raaf's senior position but prime minister robert menzies insisted on a british officer commanding the service over the protest of his minister for air james fairbairn and the raf's air chief marshal sir charles burnett became cas

lines.value: in his volume in the official history of the air force in world war ii douglas gillison observed that considering williams intimate knowledge of the raaf and its problems and his long experience commanding the service it is difficult to see what contribution burnett was expected to make that was beyond williams capacity
lines.name: English

lines.value: williams was appointed air member for organisation and equipment and promoted to air marshal the first man in the raaf to achieve this rank

lines.value: williams returned to england in october 1941 to set up raaf overseas headquarters co ordinating services for the many australians posted there

lines.value: he maintained that australian airmen in europe and the mediterranean should serve in raaf units to preserve their national identity as per article xv of the empire air training scheme rather than be integrated into raf squadrons but in practice most served in british units

lines.value: even nominally raaf squadrons formed under the scheme were rarely composed primarily of australians and williams efforts to establish a distinct raaf group within bomber command similar to the royal canadian air force's no

lines.value: he was able to negotiate improved conditions for raaf personnel in europe including full australian pay scales as opposed to the lower raf rates that were offered initially

lines.value: when air chief marshal burnett completed his term in 1942 williams was once more considered for the role of cas
