lines.value: piers anthony dillingham jacob born 6 august 1934 in oxford england is an english american author in the science fiction and fantasy genres publishing under the name piers anthony
lines.name: English

lines.value: he is most famous for his set in the fictional realm of xanth
lines.name: English

lines.value: many of his books have appeared on the new york times best seller list
lines.name: English

lines.value: he has stated that one of his greatest achievements has been to publish a book beginning with every letter of the alphabet from anthonology to zombie lover
lines.name: English

lines.value: anthony's parents alfred and norma jacob were quaker pacifists studying at oxford university who interrupted their studies in 1936 to undertake relief work on behalf of the quakers during the spanish civil war establishing a food kitchen for children in barcelona
lines.name: English

lines.value: piers and his sister were left in england in the care of their maternal grandparents and a nanny
lines.name: English

lines.value: alfred jacob although a british citizen had been born in america near philadelphia and in 1940 after being forced out of spain and with the situation in britain deteriorating the family sailed to the united states
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1941 the family settled in a rustic back to the land utopian community near winhall vermont where a young piers made the acquaintance of radical author scott nearing a neighbor
lines.name: English

lines.value: both parents resumed their academic studies and alfred eventually became a professor of romance languages teaching at a number of colleges in the philadelphia area
lines.name: English

lines.value: piers was moved around to a number of schools eventually enrolling in goddard college in vermont where he graduated in 1956
lines.name: English

lines.value: on this american life on 27 july 2012 anthony revealed that his parents had divorced he was bullied and he had poor grades in school
lines.name: English

lines.value: anthony referred to his high school as a very fancy private school and refuses to donate money to the school because as a student he recalls being part of the lower crust and that no one paid attention to or cared about him
lines.name: English

lines.value: he said i didn't like being a member of the underclass of the peons like that
lines.name: English

lines.value: he became a naturalized us citizen while serving in the united states army in 1958
lines.name: English

lines.value: after completing a two year stint in military service he briefly taught school at admiral farragut academy in st petersburg florida before becoming a full time writer
lines.name: English

lines.value: anthony met his future wife carol marble while both were attending college
lines.name: English

lines.value: they were married in 1956 the same year he graduated from goddard college
lines.name: English

lines.value: after a series of odd jobs anthony decided to join the us army in 1957 for a steady source of income and medical coverage for his pregnant wife
lines.name: English

lines.value: he would stay in the army until 1959 and became a us citizen during this time
lines.name: English

lines.value: while in the army he became an editor and cartoonist for the battalion newspaper
lines.name: English

lines.value: after leaving the army he spent a brief stint as a public school teacher before trying his hand at becoming a full time writer
lines.name: English

lines.value: anthony and his wife made a deal if he could sell a piece of writing within one year she would continue to work to support him
lines.name: English

lines.value: but if he could not sell anything in that year then he would forever give up his dream of being a writer
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the end of the year he managed to get a short story published
lines.name: English

lines.value: he credits his wife as the person who made his writing career possible and he advises aspiring writers that they need to have a source of income other than their writing in order to get through the early years of a writing career
lines.name: English

lines.value: on multiple occasions anthony has moved from one publisher to another taking a profitable hit series with him when he says he felt the editors were unduly tampering with his work

lines.value: he has sued publishers for accounting malfeasance and won judgments in his favor

lines.value: anthony maintains an internet publishers survey in the interest of helping aspiring writers

lines.value: for this service he won the 2003 friend of epic award for service to the electronic publishing community
lines.name: English

lines.value: his website won the special recognition for service to writers award from preditors and editors an author's guide to publishers and writing services
lines.name: English

lines.value: many of his popular novel series have been optioned for movies
lines.name: English

lines.value: his popular series xanth inspired the dos video game companions of xanth by legend entertainment

lines.value: the series also spawned the board game xanth by mayfair games

lines.value: anthony's novels usually end with a chapter long author's note in which he talks about himself his life and his experiences as they related to the process of writing the novel
lines.name: English

lines.value: he often discusses correspondence with readers and any real world issues that influenced the novel

lines.value: in 1987 at age 15 he decided to run away to florida in order to try to live with piers anthony

lines.name: English

lines.value: after she told her father dad i just don't like those to be scared

lines.value: would you write something with dragons in it he wrote the eyes of the dragon which was originally published in 1984 and later in 1987 by viking press

lines.value: early in anthony's literary career there was a dispute surrounding the original publication 1976 of but what of earth
lines.name: English

lines.value: editor roger elwood commissioned the novel for his nascent science fiction line laser books
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to anthony he completed but what of earth and elwood accepted and purchased it
lines.name: English

lines.value: elwood then told anthony that he wished to make several minor changes and in order not to waste anthony's time he had hired copy editor and author robert coulson to retype the manuscript with the changes
lines.name: English

lines.value: anthony described coulson as a friend and was initially open to his contribution
lines.name: English

lines.value: however elwood told coulson he was to be a full collaborator free to make revisions to anthony's text in line with suggestions made by other copy editors
lines.name: English

lines.value: elwood promised coulson a 50-50 split with anthony on all future royalties
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to anthony the published novel was very different from his version with changes to characters and dialog and with scenes added and removed
lines.name: English

lines.value: anthony felt the changes worsened the novel
lines.name: English

lines.value: laser's ultimate publication of but what of earth
lines.name: English

lines.value: listed anthony and coulson together as collaborators
lines.name: English

lines.value: publication rights were reverted to anthony under threat of legal action
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1989 anthony re)published his original but what of earth
lines.name: English

lines.value: in an annotated edition through tor books
lines.name: English

lines.value: this edition contains an introduction and conclusion setting out the story of the novel's permutations and roughly 60 pages of notes by anthony giving examples of changes to plot and characters and describing some of the comments made by copy editors on his manuscript

lines.value: anthony currently lives with his wife on a tree farm which he owns in florida

lines.value: andorra la vella (,, , ) is the capital of the principality of andorra
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is located high in the east pyrenees between france and spain
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is also the name of the parish that surrounds the capital
lines.name: English

lines.value: , the city has a population of 22886 and the urban area which includes escaldes engordany plus satellite villages has over 40000 inhabitants
lines.name: English

lines.value: the principal industry is tourism although the country also earns foreign income from being a tax haven
lines.name: English

lines.value: furniture and brandies are local products
lines.name: English

lines.value: being at an elevation of 1023 metres 3356 ft it is the highest capital city in europe and a popular ski resort
lines.name: English

lines.value: the site of andorra la vella literally andorra the old in catalan has been settled since prior to the christian era notably by the andosin tribe from the late neolithic
lines.name: English

lines.value: the state is one of the marca hispanica created and protected by charlemagne in the eighth century as a buffer from the moorish settlers in the iberian peninsula
lines.name: English

lines.value: the settlement of andorra la vella has been the principal city of andorra since 1278 when the french and the episcopal co princes agreed to joint suzerainty
lines.name: English

lines.value: andorra la vella's old town the barri antic includes streets and buildings dating from this time
lines.name: English

lines.value: its most notable building is the casa de la vall constructed in the early sixteenth century which has been the state's parliamentary house since 1702
lines.name: English

lines.value: andorra la vella was during this period the capital of a largely isolated and feudal state which retained its independence due to this principle of co sovereignty
lines.name: English

lines.value: well into the twentieth century the area around andorra la vella remained largely forgotten indeed the state was not part of the treaty of versailles simply because it was not noticed
lines.name: English

lines.value: after political turmoil in the 1930s and an attempted coup by boris skossyreff an informal democracy developed
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1993 the country's first constitution formalised this parliamentary democracy with executive legislative and judicial branches located in andorra la vella
lines.name: English

lines.value: during this period andorra also developed as a tax haven resulting in the construction of modern banking offices in andorra la vella
lines.name: English

lines.value: the city also developed its skiing facilities to the extent that andorra la vella was andorra's applicant city for the xxi olympic winter games the 2010 winter olympics
lines.name: English

lines.value: however andorra la vella was not selected by the ioc as a candidate city following the evaluation report of an ioc commission
lines.name: English

lines.value: it also hosted both the 1991 and 2005 games of the small states of europe
lines.name: English

lines.value: andorra la vella is located in the south west of andorra at at the confluence of two mountain streams the valira del nord northern valira and the valira de l'orient eastern valira which join to form the gran valira
lines.name: English

lines.value: it adjoins the urban area of escaldes engordany
lines.name: English

lines.value: the city is at above sea level
lines.name: English

lines.value: andorra la vella has an oceanic climate cfb according to the koppen climate classification with mild summers and chilly to cold snowy winters
lines.name: English

lines.value: the average annual precipitation is
lines.name: English

lines.value: temperatures are lowered by the altitude compared with lowland areas
lines.name: English

lines.value: the parish of andorra la vella is divided into the villages of andorra la vella itself la margineda and santa coloma
lines.name: English

lines.value: the city's old town is characterized by old stone streets and houses
lines.name: English

lines.value: the central esglesia de sant esteve saint stephen church is part of the area that guidebooks often label as a picturesque part of the city
lines.name: English

lines.value: this was built in a romanesque style in the eleventh century
lines.name: English

lines.value: as mentioned earlier the old town also includes the country's historic parliament building
lines.name: English

lines.value: probably the oldest building in the city is another church dating from the ninth century of santa coloma
lines.name: English

lines.value: native andorrans who are ethnically catalan account for only a third 33% of the population with the plurality being spanish 43% both spanish and catalan speaking and notable minorities of portuguese 11% and french 7%
lines.name: English

lines.value: the city is the country's cultural centre with the government exhibition hall acting as a main theatre and museum
lines.name: English

lines.value: the piazza outside the parliament building is also the location of a number of events and the town hosts a music festival every winter
lines.name: English

lines.value: catalan is the official language although spanish portuguese and french are also spoken
lines.name: English

lines.value: most of the inhabitants are roman catholics with a high life expectancy of over 80 years
lines.name: English

lines.value: andorra la vella is the country's commercial centre
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the country as a whole 80% of the gdp is derived from the 10 million tourists who visit annually
lines.name: English

lines.value: the city is also the centre for the many banks and businesses that thrive from its tax haven status
lines.name: English

lines.value: the state is not a member of the european union but has a customs arrangement with the eu and uses the euro
lines.name: English

lines.value: andorra la vella has direct access to air transportation with commercial helicopter flights from andorra la vella heliport located in the city centre
lines.name: English

lines.value: andorra la seu d'urgell airport is located south of the city and since july 2015 operates domestic routes to various airports across spain
lines.name: English

lines.value: nearby airports located in spain and france provide access to international flights with the nearest airports being perpignan 156 km away and lleida 160 km away
lines.name: English

lines.value: the largest nearby airports are toulouse tolosa girona and barcelona
lines.name: English

lines.value: andorra la vella does not have a train station although there are bus shuttle services linking the city to train stations at l'hospitalet pres l'andorre france and lleida in spain
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are also shuttle buses from barcelona girona and reus airports to andorra la vella
lines.name: English

lines.value: the instituto espanol de andorra iea a spanish international secondary school is in la margineda in andorra la vella
lines.name: English

lines.value: the spanish primary school is escuela espanola de andorra la vella
lines.name: English

lines.value: the legend of sleepy hollow is a short story of speculative fiction by american author washington irving contained in his collection of 34 essays and short stories entitled the sketch book of geoffrey crayon gent written while irving was living abroad in birmingham england the legend of sleepy hollow was first published in 1820
lines.name: English

lines.value: along with irving's companion piece rip van winkle the legend of sleepy hollow is among the earliest examples of american fiction with enduring popularity especially during halloween because of a character known as the headless horseman believed to be a hessian soldier who lost his head to a cannonball in battle
lines.name: English

lines.value: the story is set in 1790 in the countryside around the dutch settlement of tarry town historical tarrytown new york in a secluded glen called sleepy hollow
lines.name: English

lines.value: sleepy hollow is renowned for its ghosts and the haunting atmosphere that pervades the imaginations of its inhabitants and visitors
lines.name: English

lines.value: some residents say this town was bewitched during the early days of the dutch settlement
lines.name: English

lines.value: other residents say an old native american chief the wizard of his tribe held his powwows here before the country was discovered by master hendrick hudson
lines.name: English

lines.value: the most infamous spectre in the hollow is the headless horseman said to be the ghost of a hessian trooper that had his head shot off by a stray cannonball during some nameless battle of the american revolutionary war and who rides forth to the scene of battle in nightly quest of his head
lines.name: English

lines.value: the legend relates the tale of ichabod crane a lean lanky and extremely superstitious schoolmaster from connecticut who competes with abraham brom bones van brunt the town rowdy for the hand of 18-year-old katrina van tassel the daughter and sole child of a wealthy farmer baltus van tassel
lines.name: English

lines.value: ichabod crane a yankee and an outsider sees marriage to katrina as a means of procuring van tassel's extravagant wealth
lines.name: English

lines.value: bones the local hero vies with ichabod for katrina's hand playing a series of pranks on the jittery schoolmaster and the fate of sleepy hollow's fortune weighs in the balance for some time
lines.name: English

lines.value: the tension among the three is soon brought to a head
lines.name: English

lines.value: on a placid autumn night the ambitious crane attends a harvest party at the van tassels homestead
lines.name: English

lines.value: he dances partakes in the feast and listens to ghostly legends told by brom and the locals but his true aim is to propose to katrina after the guests leave
lines.name: English

lines.value: his intentions however are ill fated
lines.name: English

lines.value: after having failed to secure katrina's hand ichabod rides home heavy hearted and crestfallen through the woods between van tassel's farmstead and the sleepy hollow settlement
lines.name: English

lines.value: as he passes several purportedly haunted spots his active imagination is engorged by the ghost stories told at baltus harvest party
lines.name: English

lines.value: after nervously passing under a lightning stricken tulip tree purportedly haunted by the ghost of british spy major andre ichabod encounters a cloaked rider at an intersection in a menacing swamp
lines.name: English

lines.value: unsettled by his fellow traveler's eerie size and silence the teacher is horrified to discover that his companion's head is not on his shoulders but on his saddle
lines.name: English

lines.value: in a frenzied race to the bridge adjacent to the old dutch burying ground where the hessian is said to vanish according to rule in a flash of fire and brimstone upon crossing it ichabod rides for his life desperately goading his temperamental plow horse down the hollow
lines.name: English

lines.value: however to crane's horror the ghoul clambers over the bridge rears his horse and hurls his severed head into ichabod's terrified face
lines.name: English

lines.value: the next morning ichabod has mysteriously disappeared from town leaving katrina to marry brom bones who was said to look exceedingly knowing whenever the story of ichabod was related
lines.name: English

lines.value: indeed the only relics of the schoolmaster's flight are his wandering horse trampled saddle discarded hat and a mysterious shattered pumpkin
lines.name: English

lines.value: although the nature of the headless horseman is left open to interpretation the story implies that the ghost was really brom an agile stunt rider in disguise
lines.name: English

lines.value: irving's narrator concludes however by stating that the old dutch wives continue to promote the belief that ichabod was spirited away by supernatural means and a legend develops around his disappearance and sightings of his melancholy spirit
lines.name: English

lines.value: irving wrote the sketch book during a tour of europe and parts of the tale may also be traced to european origins
lines.name: English

lines.value: headless horsemen were staples of northern european storytelling featuring in german irish e.g dullahan scandinavian e.g the wild hunt and english legends and were included in robert burns's poem tam o shanter 1790 and burger's der wilde jager translated as the wild huntsman 1796
lines.name: English

lines.value: usually viewed as omens of ill fortune for those who chose to disregard their apparitions these specters found their victims in proud scheming persons and characters with hubris and arrogance
lines.name: English

lines.value: one particularly influential rendition of this folktale was recorded by the german folklorist karl musaus
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the height of the american revolutionary war irving writes that the country surrounding tarry town was one of those highly favored places which abound with chronicle and great men
lines.name: English

lines.value: the british and american line had run near it during the war it had therefore been the scene of marauding and infested with refugees cow boys and all kinds of border chivalry after the battle of white plains in october 1776 the country south of the bronx river was abandoned by the continental army and occupied by the british
lines.name: English

lines.value: the americans were fortified north of peekskill leaving westchester county a 30-mile stretch of scorched and desolated no man's land vulnerable to outlaws raiders and vigilantes
lines.name: English

lines.value: besides droves of loyalist rangers and british light infantry hessian jagers-renowned sharpshooters and horsemen were among the raiders who often skirmished with patriot militias
lines.name: English

lines.value: the headless horseman said to be a decapitated hessian soldier may have indeed been based loosely on the discovery of just such a jager's headless corpse found in sleepy hollow after a violent skirmish and later buried by the van tassel family in an unmarked grave in the old dutch burying ground
lines.name: English

lines.value: the denouement of the fictional tale is set at the bridge over the pocantico river in the area of the old dutch church and burying ground in sleepy hollow
lines.name: English

lines.value: irving while he was an aide de camp to new york gov daniel d tompkins met an army captain named ichabod crane in sackets harbor new york during an inspection tour of fortifications in 1814
lines.name: English

lines.value: irving may have patterned the character in the legend after jesse merwin who taught at the local schoolhouse in kinderhook further north along the hudson river where irving spent several months in 1809
lines.name: English

lines.value: the inspiration for the character of katrina van tassel is uncertain
lines.name: English

lines.value: the story was the longest one published as part of the sketch book of geoffrey crayon gent
lines.name: English

lines.value: commonly referred to as the sketch book which irving issued serially throughout 1819 and 1820 using the pseudonym geoffrey crayon
lines.name: English

lines.value: with rip van winkle the legend of sleepy hollow is one of irving's most anthologized studied and adapted sketches
lines.name: English

lines.value: both stories are often paired together in books and other representations and both are included in surveys of early american literature and romanticism
lines.name: English

lines.value: irving's depictions of regional culture and his themes of progress versus tradition supernatural intervention in the commonplace and the plight of the individual outsider in an homogeneous community permeate both stories and helped to develop a unique sense of american cultural and existential selfhood during the early 19th century
lines.name: English

lines.value: columbia formerly wright's ferry is a borough town in lancaster county pennsylvania 28 miles 45 km southeast of harrisburg on the east left bank of the susquehanna river across from wrightsville and york county and just south of us route 30
lines.name: English

lines.value: the settlement was founded in 1726 by colonial english quakers from chester county led by entrepreneur and evangelist john wright
lines.name: English

lines.value: establishment of the eponymous wright's ferry the first commercial susquehanna crossing in the region inflamed territorial conflict with neighboring maryland but brought growth and prosperity to the small town which was just a few votes shy of becoming the new united states capital
lines.name: English

lines.value: though besieged for a short while by civil war destruction columbia remained a lively center of transport and industry throughout the 19th century once serving as a terminus of the pennsylvania canal
lines.name: English

lines.value: later however the great depression and 20th-century changes in economy and technology sent the borough into decline
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is notable today as the site of one of the world's few museums devoted entirely to horology
lines.name: English

lines.value: the area around present day columbia was originally populated by native american tribes most notably the susquehannocks who migrated to the area between 1575 and 1600 after separating from the iroquois confederacy
lines.name: English

lines.value: they established villages just south of columbia in what is now washington boro as well as claiming at least hunting lands as far south as maryland and northern virginia.<ref name="amheritagebk"> captain john smith reported on the susquehannock in glowing superlatives when a traveling group visited jamestown virginia he estimated their numbers to be about 2000 in the early 1600s
lines.name: English

lines.value: the french ran across them in the area around buffalo apparently visiting the wenro and suggesting their numbers were far greater
lines.name: English

lines.value: the province of maryland fought a declared war for nearly a decade signing a peace in 1632 against the susquehannock confederation who were allied to new sweden and furnishing fire arms to the susquehannocks in exchange for furs
lines.name: English

lines.value: the american heritage book of indians reports the tribe occupied the entire susquehanna drainage basin from the divide with the mohawk river in lower new york state and part of the west side of the chesapeake bay in the province of virginia while noting the confederation numbered between 10-20000 in the mid 1660s when they came close to wiping out two nations of the iroquois
lines.name: English

lines.value: an virulent epidemic struck the susquehannock towns during 1668 or 1669 and is believed to have lasted or recurred or morphed to plagues of other disease possibly killing up to 90% of the amerindian nations people
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1671-1672 they were beset on all sides —with attacks from colonial settlers raids from the weakened iroquois and the long subjugated lenape band occupying the poconos and lehigh valley
lines.name: English

lines.value: in that decade pennsylvania connecticut and new york all claimed the susquehannock lands of the wyoming valley where the remnants of the nation were to recoil into a few scant under populated towns
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1678 the governor of new york would sign a treaty with the league of the iroquois requiring them to take in the susquehannocks
lines.name: English

lines.value: the iroquoian cultures universally supporting adoption absorbed the people
lines.name: English

lines.value: small bands moved west across the susquehanna to new villages such as conestoga town and some are believed to have trekked through the gaps of the allegheny to the virtually empty lands beyond the alleghenies perhaps mingling there with other iroquoian peoples such as the seneca wenro and erie peoples forming the new clans and towns as the new mingo people whose small bands known to be present in western pennsylvania and eastern ohio in the early 1800s
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1724 john wright an english quaker traveled to the columbia area then a part of chester county to explore the land and proselytize to a native american tribe the shawnee who had established a settlement along shawnee creek
lines.name: English

lines.value: wright built a log cabin nearby on a tract of land first granted to george beale by william penn in 1699 and stayed for more than a year
lines.name: English

lines.value: the area was then known as shawanatown
lines.name: English

lines.value: when wright returned in 1726 with companions robert barber and samuel blunston they began developing the area wright building a house about a hundred yards from the edge of the susquehanna river in the area of today's south second and union streets
lines.name: English

lines.value: susanna wright later built wright's ferry mansion the oldest existing house in columbia dating 1738
lines.name: English

lines.value: she live in this house with her brother james and his wife rhoda and possibly the first of their many children
lines.name: English

lines.value: the home is open for tours as a house museum and is located at second and cherry streets
lines.name: English

lines.value: robert barber constructed a sawmill in 1727 and later built a home near the river on the washington boro pike along what is now route 441
lines.name: English

lines.value: the home still stands across from the columbia wastewater treatment plant and is the second oldest in the borough after wright's ferry mansion
lines.name: English

lines.value: samuel blunston constructed a mansion called bellmont atop the hill next to north second street near chestnut street at the location of the present day rotary park playground
lines.name: English

lines.value: upon his death blunston willed the mansion to susanna wright who had become a close friend
lines.name: English

lines.value: she lived there occasionally visiting brother james ministering to the native americans and raising silkworms for the local silk industry until her death in 1784 at the age of 87
lines.name: English

lines.value: the residence was demolished in the late 1920s to allow for construction of the veterans memorial bridge
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1729 after wright had petitioned william penn's son to create a new county the provincial government took land from chester county to establish lancaster county the fourth county in pennsylvania
lines.name: English

lines.value: county residents - indians and colonists alike - regularly traveled to wright's home to file papers and claims seek government assistance and redress of issues and register land deeds
lines.name: English

lines.value: the area was particularly attractive to pennsylvania dutch settlers
lines.name: English

lines.value: during this time the town was called wright's ferry
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1730 john wright was granted a patent to operate a ferry across the susquehanna river subsequently established with barber and blunston as wright's ferry
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also built a ferry house and a two story log tavern on the eastern shore north of locust street on front street
lines.name: English

lines.value: the ferry itself originally consisted of two dugout canoes fastened together with carriage and wagon wheels and drawn by cattle
lines.name: English

lines.value: crossings could be a dangerous enterprise
lines.name: English

lines.value: when several oxen were moved at once the canoeist guided a lead animal with a rope so that the others would follow if however the lead animal became confused and started swimming in circles the other animals followed until they tired and eventually drowned
lines.name: English

lines.value: typical fares in the 1700s were traffic heading west from lancaster philadelphia and other nearby towns regularly traveled through columbia using the ferry to cross the susquehanna
lines.name: English

lines.value: as traffic flow increased the ferry grew to the point of including canoes rafts flatboats and eventually steamboats it became capable of handling conestoga wagons and other large vehicles
lines.name: English

lines.value: due to the volume of traffic however wagons freight supplies and people often became backed up creating a waiting period of several days to cross the river
lines.name: English

lines.value: with 150 to 200 vehicles lined up on the columbia side ferrymen used chalk to number the wagons
lines.name: English

lines.value: wright's ferry was the first convenient crossing of the susquehanna river in the region
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the time however southern pennsylvania above the 40th parallel was claimed by the province of maryland which took especial interest in the rural area around the ferry
lines.name: English

lines.value: fearing an influx of pennsylvanian settlers that could weaken maryland's influence maryland colonist thomas cresap under the aegis of lord baltimore attempted to establish a competing ferry and a strong landholding presence around the susquehanna
lines.name: English

lines.value: pennsylvanians responded in kind a violent attack on cresap in october 1730 escalated the situation into a series of bitter if not bloody militia skirmishes and heated legal battles
lines.name: English

lines.value: the situation was not fully resolved until a london peace agreement in 1738 which cooled the colonies territorial dispute and set the stage for the later codification of the mason–dixon line
lines.name: English

lines.value: samuel wright son of james and rhoda wright was born on may 12 1754
lines.name: English

lines.value: he eventually became the town proprietor and created a public grounds company to administer the land
lines.name: English

lines.value: through his trusteeship the town's first water distribution system later the columbia water company was established as well as the washington institute the town's first school of higher learning and the locust street park located at what is now locust street and route 462
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the spring of 1788 samuel wright had the area surveyed and formally laid out the town into 160 building lots which were distributed by lottery at 15 shillings per ticket
lines.name: English

lines.value: adventurers as purchasers were known included speculators from many areas of the country
lines.name: English

lines.value: wright and town citizens renamed the town columbia in honor of christopher columbus in the hope of influencing the new us congress to select it as the nation's capital a plan george washington favored a formal proposal to do so was made in 1789
lines.name: English

lines.value: unfortunately for the town when congress voted in 1790 the final tally was one vote short
lines.name: English

lines.value: later columbia narrowly missed becoming the capital of pennsylvania harrisburg was chosen instead being closer to the state's geographical center
lines.name: English

lines.value: english anglicans scots irish presbyterians freed african slaves german lutherans and descendants of french huguenots came to outnumber the first quaker settlers within a generation
lines.name: English

lines.value: columbia became an incorporated borough in 1814 formed out of hempfield township
lines.name: English

lines.value: the same year the world's longest covered bridge was built across the susquehanna to wrightsville facilitating traffic flow across the river and reducing the need for the ferry
lines.name: English

lines.value: the bridge was long and wide and had 54 stone piers
lines.name: English

lines.value: after handling traffic across the susquehanna for 18 years it was destroyed by high water ice and severe weather in the winter of 1832
lines.name: English

lines.value: a replacement covered bridge the pennsylvania railroad bridge was built within two years
lines.name: English

lines.value: in february 1826 the pennsylvania state legislature approved the package of legislation known as the main line of public works with the goal of connecting the width and breadth of pennsylvania by the best and most reliable transportation known water transport
lines.name: English

lines.value: the project started with the harder parts up the juniata river and over the mountains being funded first
lines.name: English

lines.value: $300000 in the funding was for the construction of a navigation that would be called the pennsylvania canal along the susquehanna's eastern shore to bypass rapids and shallows and make the river navigable anywhere along its route
lines.name: English

lines.value: also as conceived another 82 mile canal would be dug from the terminus in columbia to connect towns to the east with a terminus on the delaware river at philadelphia
lines.name: English

lines.value: across the alleghenies another canal would connect the allegheny portage railroad crossing the mountains to the ohio river and the mississippi river ensuring the port of philadelphia would dominate inland trade and manufacturing in the exploding trans appalachian territories
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was a brave far looking ambitious vision
lines.name: English

lines.value: like the erie canal which was completed in 1825 the very year the legislation package came to be filed the overall scheme was envisioned when water transport was the fastest means of travel over any long distance was the best way to ship heavy bulk goods or cumbersome loads—and was before railways came to the public eye and their technology had been refined enough to become working propositions
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1836 there were probably less than six railways in the world
lines.name: English

lines.value: in that reality the navigations were finally begun in 1832 after several delays the work went quickly and pennsylvania canal went into operation in 1833
lines.name: English

lines.value: it started at columbia stretching north to the junction of the juniata river
lines.name: English

lines.value: the intent was that goods and travelers could use the canal system to go west from columbia to pittsburgh lake erie ohio and [present-day] west virginia along the juniata division or by taking the main susquehanna northwards northern division reach north central pennsylvania and into lower new york state
lines.name: English

lines.value: when the reality met conception the plan broke
lines.name: English

lines.value: engineering studies found no reasonably feasible way to provide enough water to keep an 82-mile canal to philadelphia wet much less support lock operations
lines.name: English

lines.value: when that was reported the pennsylvania canal commission came up with a new plan one using the right of way authorized to build one of these newfangled railways that were making news
lines.name: English

lines.value: their solution was the philadelphia and columbia railroad one of the first common carrier commercial railways to operate in the united states
lines.name: English

lines.value: double tracked it utilized two inclined plane cable railways at steep rises near either end and except for bypasses of that older technology unneeded with more powerful locomotives the p&cr trackage is still in use today as it passed to the pennsylvania railroad in 1857 along with most of the pennsylvania canal
lines.name: English

lines.value: canal boats could often be seen at the bruner coal wharf operated by hf bruner & sons at north front and bridge streets
lines.name: English

lines.value: the canal was originally planned to extend south from columbia on the east side of the river but local property owners objected
lines.name: English

lines.value: instead a two tiered towpath was constructed along the south side of the bridge to transport boats across the river using horse and mule teams
lines.name: English

lines.value: the boats then linked with the susquehanna and tidewater canal along the western shore at wrightsville
lines.name: English

lines.value: this part of the canal system which afforded passage to baltimore or the chesapeake and delaware canal opened in 1840
lines.name: English

lines.value: several years later a small dam was constructed across the river to form a pool that allowed steamboats to tow the canal boats
lines.name: English

lines.value: canals could not be used in winter due to ice and floods which caused damage that had to be repaired in the spring
lines.name: English

lines.value: these limitations combined with an increase in railroad traffic led to the decline of the canals
lines.name: English

lines.value: the columbia canal finally closed in 1901 the same year that wright's ferry ceased to operate
lines.name: English

lines.value: during this time columbia also became a stop on the underground railroad
lines.name: English

lines.value: slaves seeking freedom were transported across the susquehanna fed and given supplies on their way north to other states and canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: to slave hunters from the south the slaves seemed to simply disappear leading one hunter to declare that there must be an underground railroad here any idealistic view of abolition in columbia is surely tested however by the occurrence of a significant race riot in 1834
lines.name: English

lines.value: the riot erupted in august of that year when white workers revolted against working alongside black freedmen
lines.name: English

lines.value: citing a document drafted by the rioters themselves historian david roediger explains that typical of other race riots of the period white rioters feared a plot by employers and abolitionists to open new trades to blacks and to break down the distinctive barrier between the colors that the poor whites may gradually sink into the degraded condition of the negroes that like them they may be slaves and tools the rioters declaration called for colored freeholders to be singled out for removal from the borough
lines.name: English

lines.value: the riot resulted in a large number of african american residents being forced from their homes and their property destroyed
lines.name: English

lines.value: 1834 saw the completion of another bridge spanning the river
lines.name: English

lines.value: built by james moore and john evans at a cost of $157300 this bridge too enjoyed the distinction of being the world's longest covered bridge
lines.name: English

lines.value: this year also saw construction of the first railway line linking columbia and philadelphia which subsequently became part of the pennsylvania railroad
lines.name: English

lines.value: named the philadelphia and columbia railroad it officially opened in october 1834
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1852 regular rail transportation from columbia to baltimore philadelphia pittsburgh and harrisburg made the town the commercial center for the area halfway between the county seats of lancaster and york
lines.name: English

lines.value: in early 1863 as the american civil war raged a number of local black citizens enlisted in the 54th massachusetts infantry a regiment composed of black soldiers serving under white officers
lines.name: English

lines.value: the unit achieved fame in an assault on fort wagner in south carolina
lines.name: English

lines.value: stephen swails one of its members may have been the first african american officer commissioned during the civil war
lines.name: English

lines.value: other local citizens fought in various regiments of the united states colored troops
lines.name: English

lines.value: some of these veterans are buried in a cemetery located near fifth street
lines.name: English

lines.value: on june 28 1863 during the gettysburg campaign the replacement covered bridge was burned by columbia residents and the pennsylvania state militia to prevent confederate soldiers of the army of northern virginia from entering lancaster county
lines.name: English

lines.value: general robert e lee had hoped to invade harrisburg from the rear and move eastward to lancaster and philadelphia and in the process destroy railroad yards and other facilities
lines.name: English

lines.value: under general jubal a early's command and following lee's orders general john b gordon was to place lancaster and the surrounding farming area under contribution for the confederate army's war supplies and to attack harrisburg from the east side of the river while another portion of lee's army advanced from the west side
lines.name: English

lines.value: general early was given orders to burn the bridge but hoped instead to capture it while union forces under the command of colonel jacob g frick and major granville o haller hoping to save the bridge were forced to burn it
lines.name: English

lines.value: owners of the bridge petitioned congress repeatedly for reimbursement well into the 1960s but were denied payment
lines.name: English

lines.value: with the union army of the potomac hastening northward into maryland and pennsylvania robert e lee ordered his widely scattered forces to withdraw to heidlersburg and cashtown not far from gettysburg to rendezvous with other contingents of the confederate army
lines.name: English

lines.value: the burning of the columbia wrightsville bridge thwarted one of lee's goals for the invasion of pennsylvania and general gordon later claimed the skirmish at wrightsville reinforced the erroneous confederate belief that the only defensive forces on hand were inefficient local militia an attitude that carried over to the first day of the battle of gettysburg
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the wartime bridge burning a tugboat columbia was used to tow canal boats across the river
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1868 yet another replacement covered bridge was built but was destroyed by a hurricane in 1896
lines.name: English

lines.value: the next bridge the pennsylvania railroad bridge was a steel open bridge which carried the tracks of the pennsylvania railroad and a two lane roadway for cars
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was dismantled for scrap by november 1964 but its stone piers which supported the civil war era bridge can still be seen today running parallel to the veterans memorial bridge on route 462
lines.name: English

lines.value: the piers have become the site of present day flames across the susquehanna bridge burning reenactments sponsored by rivertownes pa usa
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1875 a new three story grand town hall opened featuring a second floor auditorium that seated over 900 and was used as an opera house
lines.name: English

lines.value: the second floor's ceiling was higher than those of the first and third floors each level contained 60 windows
lines.name: English

lines.value: the building also included office shops council chambers storerooms and market stalls
lines.name: English

lines.value: a high bell tower holding the town clock crowned the building
lines.name: English

lines.value: the clock was visible from all over the borough and its bell was audible throughout the surrounding countryside
lines.name: English

lines.value: the building was destroyed by fire in february 1947 but was rebuilt as a one story municipal building that exists today
lines.name: English

lines.value: trolley service for the borough and surrounding area was established in 1893 allowing columbians to take advantage of economic opportunities in lancaster and other nearby towns
lines.name: English

lines.value: between 1830 and 1900 the borough's population increased from 2046 to 12316
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the mid 19th century columbia had become a busy transportation hub with its ferry bridge canal railroad and wharves
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was a major shipping transfer point for lumber coal grain pig iron and people
lines.name: English

lines.value: important industries of the time included warehousing tobacco processing iron production clockmaking and boat building
lines.name: English

lines.value: prominent local companies included the ashley and bailey silk mill the columbia lace mill and hf bruner & sons
lines.name: English

lines.value: from about 1854 to 1900 an industrial complex existed in and around columbia marietta and wrightsville that included 11 anthracite iron furnaces and related structures as well as canal and railroad facilities servicing them
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1887 that number had grown to 13 blast furnaces all operating within a three mile 5 km radius of columbia
lines.name: English

lines.value: the furnaces which produced pig iron exemplified the technology of the day through their use of anthracite coal and hot blast for smelting iron ore a process that dominated the iron industry before the widespread use of coke as a fuel
lines.name: English

lines.value: since northeastern pennsylvania was a rich source of anthracite coal anthracite fired furnaces using locally available iron ores were built throughout eastern pennsylvania helping to make the state a leader in iron production in the latter half of the 19th century
lines.name: English

lines.value: lancaster county also became a leader in pig iron production during this time with the river towns complex of furnaces contributing significantly to its output
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1900 the town's population had grown to over 12000 with a 50% increase from 1880 to 1900
lines.name: English

lines.value: some of the items produced by its industries were silk goods lace pipe laundry machinery stoves iron toys flour lumber and wagons
lines.name: English

lines.value: by this time wright's ferry had ceased its operations having been supplanted by rail and bridge traffic
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1930 yet another bridge the veterans memorial bridge was opened to improve traffic flow across the susquehanna
lines.name: English

lines.value: it first opened as a toll bridge to avoid the toll in the coldest winter months some daring motorists would cross on the firmly frozen river
lines.name: English

lines.value: later that same decade many of the city's brick sidewalks were converted to concrete the bronze plaques of the concrete installers are still visible today
lines.name: English

lines.value: the start of the 20th century brought economic challenge to columbia as local industries declined
lines.name: English

lines.value: the lumber industry eventually disappeared as surrounding woodlands became depleted
lines.name: English

lines.value: as chestnut hill iron ores became scarce as well the iron furnaces shut down
lines.name: English

lines.value: eventually the steel rolling mills also ceased operation
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1906 the pennsylvania railroad opened a new facility in enola across the river from harrisburg which decreased the significance of columbia's railroad
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1920 the population had dropped over 10% to 10836
lines.name: English

lines.value: the great depression accelerated columbia's economic slide
lines.name: English

lines.value: the pennsylvania railroad's service to the north and the south was eliminated
lines.name: English

lines.value: world war ii increased employment but did not bring long term prosperity to the borough
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1960 population had returned to its 1900 level
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1965 a detailed study of columbia's basic strengths and weaknesses was released but its suggestions went mostly unheeded
lines.name: English

lines.value: the wright's ferry bridge which opened in 1972 only served to divert traffic around columbia
lines.name: English

lines.value: the growth and prosperity experienced in some lancaster county towns bypassed columbia for the remainder of the 20th century
lines.name: English

lines.value: although the united states census bureau reported that as of the last year of the 20th century the population of columbia had been only 10311 people by 2010 this figure had grown to 10400
lines.name: English

lines.value: the susquehanna river flows past the borough of columbia into the chesapeake bay
lines.name: English

lines.value: the city of lancaster is the county seat
lines.name: English

lines.value: for over half a century columbia has been home to the headquarters of the national association of watch and clock collectors nawcc whose campus on poplar street includes a clock tower clock museum library research center and school of horology for training professional clock and watch repairers

lines.value: cedar rapids is the second largest city in iowa and is the county seat of linn county
lines.name: English

lines.value: the city lies on both banks of the cedar river north of iowa city and northeast of des moines the state's capital and largest city
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is a part of the cedar rapids/iowa city corridor of linn benton cedar jones johnson and washington counties
lines.name: English

lines.value: as of the 2010 united states census the city population was 126326
lines.name: English

lines.value: the estimated population of the three county metropolitan statistical area which includes the nearby cities of marion and hiawatha was 255452 in 2008
lines.name: English

lines.value: cedar rapids is an economic hub of the state located in the core of the interstate 380
lines.name: English

lines.value: a flourishing center for arts and culture in eastern iowa the city is home to the cedar rapids museum of art the national czech & slovak museum & library the paramount theatre orchestra iowa theatre cedar rapids the african american historical museum and cultural center of iowa the iowa cultural corridor alliance
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1990s and 2000s several cedar rapidians became well known actors including bobby driscoll ashton kutcher elijah wood and ron livingston
lines.name: English

lines.value: the city is the setting for the musical the pajama game and the comedy film cedar rapids
lines.name: English

lines.value: among the famous people who have lived in cedar rapids are american gothic painter grant wood journalist and historian william l shirer writer and photographer carl van vechten and aerodynamics pioneer dr alexander lippisch
lines.name: English

lines.value: the area has also produced professional athletes such as landon cassill ryan sweeney trent green zach johnson and kurt warner as well as mark walter co owner and chairman of baseball's los angeles dodgers
lines.name: English

lines.value: cedar rapids is nicknamed the city of five seasons for the fifth season which is time to enjoy the other four
lines.name: English

lines.value: the symbol of the five seasons is the tree of five seasons sculpture in downtown along the north river bank
lines.name: English

lines.value: the name five seasons and representations of the sculpture appear throughout the city in many forms
lines.name: English

lines.value: the location of present day cedar rapids was in the territory of the fox and sac tribes
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first permanent settler osgood shepherd arrived in 1838
lines.name: English

lines.value: when cedar rapids was first established in 1838 william stone named the town columbus
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1841 it was resurveyed and renamed by nb brown and his associates
lines.name: English

lines.value: they named the town cedar rapids for the rapids in the cedar river at the site and the river itself was named for the large number of red cedar trees that grew along its banks
lines.name: English

lines.value: cedar rapids was incorporated on january 15 1849
lines.name: English

lines.value: cedar rapids annexed the community of kingston in 1870
lines.name: English

lines.value: the economic growth of cedar rapids increased in 1871 upon the founding of the sinclair meatpacking company
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2010 the census bureau reported cedar rapids population as 87.98% white and 5.58% black
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the iowa flood of 2008 the cedar river reached a record high of on june 13 2008 the previous record was surpassing the 500-year flood plain
lines.name: English

lines.value: 1126 city blocks were flooded or more than 561 city blocks were severely damaged on both banks of the cedar river comprising 14% of the city's total area
lines.name: English

lines.value: there were a total of 7749 flooded properties that had to be evacuated 5900 were homes and 310 were city facilities including the city hall central fire station main public library ground transportation center public works building and animal control building
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is estimated 1300 or more properties need to be demolished in the cedar rapids area because of the flood which caused several billions of dollars in damages
lines.name: English

lines.value: more than 4000 members of the iowa national guard were activated to assist the city
lines.name: English

lines.value: the temporary levees became saturated not only with the flood waters but also with additional rainfall causing the levies to fail
lines.name: English

lines.value: until the 2008 flood the city's government was headquartered in the veterans memorial building near the linn county courthouse and jail on mays island in the cedar river making cedar rapids one of a few cities in the world along with paris france with governmental offices on a municipal island
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the flood of 2016 remnants of hurricane paine from the eastern pacific ocean via the gulf of california caused the second highest recorded crest of the cedar river in cedar rapids reaching on tuesday september 27 2016
lines.name: English

lines.value: the inundation of southern minnesota central and western wisconsin and northeastern iowa by hurricane paine's remnants began on september 21 and 22 and continued until the end of september 2016
lines.name: English

lines.value: this cresting in cedar rapids was below the initial estimate of and the revised estimate of but more than above the flood stage of
lines.name: English

lines.value: this flood was above levels considered to have about a 1 percent chance of occurring in a given year
lines.name: English

lines.value: more than 5000 homes were affected including the flooded areas around time check park the czech village and the new bohemia district causing over 5000 persons to be evacuated
lines.name: English

lines.value: the cedar rapids schools did not have school for a week
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2015 the city of cedar rapids approved a $625 million flood protection plan over 20 years for levee improvements
lines.name: English

lines.value: although the improvement to the levee system in cedar rapids had not been completed due to over $80 million in funding not appropriated by the united states congresses of 2014 and 2016 and the voting down by local residents of a temporary increase in the local sales tax to pay for the levee improvements out of school students along with hundreds of thousands of volunteers and 412 iowa national guard troops filled more than a quarter of a million sand bags in a successful effort that prevented any major flooding of the city outside of the evacuation zone
lines.name: English

lines.value: a system of hesco barriers earthen berms and over 400000 sand bags were used to plug the gaps in the levee system
lines.name: English

lines.value: the city of cedar rapids purchased additional hesco barriers from iowa city for $1.4 million
lines.name: English

lines.value: numerous upstream cities which had been earlier affected by the september flooding and mandatory evacuations including charles city greene manchester clarksville shell rock vinton janesville cedar falls and waterloo sent hundreds of thousands of unused sand bags to support efforts in cedar rapids and nearby communities
lines.name: English

lines.value: the remnants of hurricane paine did not produce any rain to saturate the temporary earth berms and sand bags which would have greatly increased the likelihood of breach in the temporary levee structures and thus causing a much greater flooded area the river crested during very sunny weather in cedar rapids
lines.name: English

lines.value: additionally beginning on the evening of sunday september 25 300 to 400 national guard troops along with the iowa state patrol other law enforcement agencies and 60 duly sworn law enforcement officials enforced an 8pm to 7am curfew nightly
lines.name: English

lines.value: two miss czech slovak us queens can claim this community as home lisa volesky and stasia krivanek

lines.value: olga drahozal was the famed band leader of the czech plus polka band a performing group that frequents the kosek band stand in czech village
lines.name: English

lines.value: she along with bessie duggena and leona poduska taught czech school ceska skola at wilson middle school

lines.value: in 2003 the african american historical museum and cultural center of iowa opened its doors
lines.name: English

lines.value: cedar rapids is also home to the historic 26 acre 105000 m² brucemore estate on which sits a 21-room mansion and the masonic library and museum
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2009 cedar rapids was rated one of the top 10 cities to grow up in in the united states partly due to a low crime rate and a good public school system
lines.name: English

lines.value: cedar rapids has a humid continental climate with long cold sometimes brutal winters with plenty of snow while summers are hot and humid with frequent severe thunderstorms
lines.name: English

lines.value: the record low temperature in cedar rapids is set on january 15 2009 while the record high temperature of was set on july 31 1988

lines.value: the national muslim cemetery on of land donated by haj
lines.name: English

lines.value: yahya william aossey in 1948 is said to be the first exclusively muslim cemetery in north america

lines.value: graves in the cemetery face mecca
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mother mosque of america dedicated on june 16 1934 is the longest standing mosque in north america

lines.value: in 1972 another mosque was built and the original mosque was sold and fell into disrepair before being purchased in 1990 by the islamic council of iowa and renovated

lines.value: from april 6 1908 to december 31 2005 cedar rapids used the city commission form of government
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was one of the few larger american cities remaining to operate under this model
lines.name: English

lines.value: under this form of government the council was made up of a public safety commissioner a streets commissioner a finance commissioner a parks commissioner and a mayor
lines.name: English

lines.value: the council members worked on a full time basis served two year terms and were considered department heads
lines.name: English

lines.value: don canney the longest serving mayor in city history served for twenty two years under this system
lines.name: English

lines.value: the last mayor of cedar rapids under this form of government was paul pate
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2005 the cedar rapids area chamber of commerce spearheaded a movement to change from the commission form of government
lines.name: English

lines.value: a panel was appointed by mayor pate and the city council to study the issue and recommended that voters be presented with three options cedar rapids now has an iowa home rule charter which establishes a weak mayor system with a part time city council and mayor both on four year terms
lines.name: English

lines.value: released on february 26 2010,the crazies is a 2010 film which fictionally takes place near cedar rapids at odgen marsh iowa
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the film residents both in and near ogden marsh become infected with a rhabdoviridae prototype biological weapon called trixie
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the end of the movie david and judy who are unaffected victims within the affected area arrive at a truck stop to search for a vehicle but discover that the national guard have also executed those who were evacuated
lines.name: English

lines.value: fending off three trixie infected persons they escape in a semi truck
lines.name: English

lines.value: in order to stop the infection from spreading the national guard destoys ogden marsh in a massive explosion
lines.name: English

lines.value: as the couple flees their truck flips in the passing shockwave
lines.name: English

lines.value: they then exit their wrecked semi and begin walking towards cedar rapids
lines.name: English

lines.value: a view from a military satellite highlights first the couple then the city of cedar rapids
lines.name: English

lines.value: the words initiate containment protocol appear signifying a new containment attempt by the national guard
lines.name: English

lines.value: later during the credits bruce aune a real newscaster from kcrg tv 9 in cedar rapids reports that an explosion originating from the dakon pendrill chemical plant started a massive fire in ogden marsh which is merely a cover story for the national guard's actual destruction of the town
lines.name: English

lines.value: bruce aune then reports that a perimeter has been set and civilians are not being allowed into the area
lines.name: English

lines.value: a trixie infected individual appears on camera just before the signal is lost

lines.value: duboistown is a borough in lycoming county pennsylvania united states
lines.name: English

lines.value: the population was 1280 at the 2000 census
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is part of the williamsport pennsylvania metropolitan statistical area
lines.name: English

lines.value: duboistown pronounced doo boys town is named for its founders john and mathias dubois who bought of land between 1852 and 1857
lines.name: English

lines.value: the dubois brothers divided their land into parcels and established the village that bears their name
lines.name: English

lines.value: john dubois left the west branch susquehanna valley before duboistown was established as a borough
lines.name: English

lines.value: he sold his business interests and moved west to clearfield county
lines.name: English

lines.value: he became quite wealthy and the city of dubois was named in his honor
lines.name: English

lines.value: the town built by the dubois brothers and established as a borough in 1878 is by no means the beginning of the history of duboistown
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is situated at the mouth of mosquito run on the banks of the west branch susquehanna river
lines.name: English

lines.value: a tribe of susquehannock indians had what appears to have been a fairly major settlement at the mouth of the creek
lines.name: English

lines.value: the early european settlers found the remains of an indian village there
lines.name: English

lines.value: arhaeologic evidence of earthenware soapstone ware pestles hatchets ornaments and charms were found on the land that is across the river from lycoming creek and near where the sheshequin path crossed the river
lines.name: English

lines.value: the land on which duboistown is located was first surveyed in 1769
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the time it was known as walnut bottom for the vast stands of black walnut that covered the alluvial plain on which the borough now stands
lines.name: English

lines.value: samuel boone cousin of daniel boone held the first warrant for land at walnut bottom
lines.name: English

lines.value: andrew culbertson was one of the first settlers to have success in the duboistown area
lines.name: English

lines.value: he purchased several tracts of land beginning in 1773 including the parcel owned by samuel boone near the mouth of mosquito run
lines.name: English

lines.value: culbertson is thought to have moved into the area by crossing an indian trail over white deer mountain that is now known as culbertson's path
lines.name: English

lines.value: he built a sawmill at the mouth of the creek soon after moving to the area and he lived in the area for several years before being forced to flee during the american revolutionary war when settlements throughout the susquehanna valley were attacked by loyalists and their indian allies
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the battle of wyoming in the summer of 1778 near what is now wilkes barre and smaller local attacks the big runaway occurred throughout the west branch susquehanna valley
lines.name: English

lines.value: settlers fled feared and actual attacks by the british and their allies
lines.name: English

lines.value: settlers abandoned their homes and fields drove their livestock south and towed their possessions on rafts on the river to sunbury
lines.name: English

lines.value: their abandoned property was burned by the attackers
lines.name: English

lines.value: some settlers soon returned only to flee again in the summer of 1779 in the little runaway
lines.name: English

lines.value: culbertson returned to the area and rebuilt his sawmill
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also built a gristmill distillery and a press that extracted nut and linseed oils
lines.name: English

lines.value: his gristmill was especially important to the development of the west branch susquehanna river valley
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was easily accessible from canoe
lines.name: English

lines.value: farmers could float their grain in their canoes or other watercraft right up to the mill
lines.name: English

lines.value: other farmers from the surrounding valleys reached his mill via culbertson's path
lines.name: English

lines.value: culbertson saw another business opportunity with the farmers who were coming to his mill
lines.name: English

lines.value: he quickly built a tavern in which the weary farmers could enjoy a drink and get some food while they waited for their grain to be ground into flour
lines.name: English

lines.value: this tavern became a popular destination for the young people of the west branch valley
lines.name: English

lines.value: today culbertson's mill and tavern are long gone and the area is a largely overgrown riverbank with an abandoned softball field that is surrounded by a railroad bridge and woods
lines.name: English

lines.value: the 200 block of summer street in duboistown is decorated for christmas each december and is known as candy cane lane
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2007 the mayor of the borough proclaimed the month of december as candy cane lane month forever more in duboistown
lines.name: English

lines.value: duboistown is located at 41.225278 -77.034953
lines.name: English
